issues.title: Feature Request: Ability to Exclude Specific Folders or Files from ctags/context map
issues.body:
Hello,

I am super excited about what is been doing here, and yeah this is the first production-ready AI coder I can use with my projects.

Super THANKS ^_^

Although I think the roadmap is more towards an automated context mapping, but giving some manual control until then could be a great option.

(And of course the following is created by GPT)

An enhancement to the current mechanism by which aider uses ctags to create the context map.

Currently, it maps all the files in the repository, but there are certain instances where some directories or files may not be necessary or might contain low-priority vendor code or other frameworks. In such cases, it would be beneficial to manually  exclude these folders or files from the map.

## Feature Description:

Adding a feature that allows users to specify directories or files to be excluded from the mapping process. This could be implemented in the form of a configuration setting or command line argument where users can provide a list of directories or files to be ignored.


## Benefit:

This feature would enable users to better control the mapping process and manage the context that GPT-4 operates in. Ignoring less relevant folders or files would not only speed up the mapping process, but also provide more space for the more relevant and important context.

issues.title: Consider switching from GitPython to another package
issues.body:
GitPython doesn't support git repos with index version newer than v2. 

https://github.com/gitpython-developers/GitPython/issues/1075

Newer versions of git can create indexes with v3 and v4:

https://git-scm.com/docs/index-format

You can work around this problem by downgrading the index format of your repo:

```
git update-index --index-version=2 
```

But it would be nice if aider used a git package that supported new index formats.

It's worth noting that dulwich currently supports v3 but not v4:

https://github.com/jelmer/dulwich/blob/master/dulwich/index.py#L309C3-L309C3
issues.author: paul-gauthier

comments.author: lmmx
comments.body:
- Related/duplicate issue: #211

I’m not sure if perhaps pygit2 might be another option to support v3+

**Edit** I checked and it seems like it does indeed support a v3 and v4 index:

```py
(pygit2) louis 🚶 ~/dev/seven $ qp
>>> import pygit2; r = pygit2.Repository("."); len(r.index)
13
>>>

comments.body:
Seems dulwich will support [index version 4](https://github.com/jelmer/dulwich/blob/c0d87d52e3efddd6a06bfeff32b2c682af276475/dulwich/index.py#L128-L243) in an upcoming release.

Alternatively, @paul-gauthier have you considered pygit2?

issues.title: Multiple Conversation Threads, Prompt Customization, and Conversation Templates
issues.body:
Another feature that could enhance the flexibility and organization of using Aider in complex or multi-faceted projects is the support for multiple conversation threads.

Feature Request:

Please add support for multiple conversation threads in Aider, enabling users to maintain separate discussions or sessions on different aspects of the same repository without interference. This feature could be managed through a --thread command line parameter, which defaults to "main" but can be set to other names to switch between independent conversation histories and file selections.

Use Case:

In projects where different components or features require distinct but simultaneous development focus, having the ability to switch contexts within the same repository environment can be invaluable. For example, one might want to discuss database issues in one thread and UI enhancements in another, without mixing the conversations and relevant file edits.

Proposed Implementation:

Introduce a --thread parameter that specifies the active conversation thread.

Store conversation-specific data like .aider.input.history and other session files in thread-specific subdirectories or encode the thread name in the file names. For instance, using an .alder directory at the top level for global configurations, and thread-XXX subdirectories for each conversation thread's data, could help keep project directories organized and avoid clutter, while enabling future extensibility and per-thread customization.

Questions for Consideration:

Version Control for .alder Files: Is it considered good practice to check in .alder files into the repo to maintain conversation history across different development environments? What are the implications for privacy and clutter in version control, and uses of pre-configured thread templates for particular tasks like chatting about documentation, apis, porting, internationalization, etc. 

Customizing Prompts per Conversation: Beyond simply including files with instructions, is there a mechanism to customize or augment the built-in AI prompts based on the conversation thread? This could tailor the assistance more closely to the context of each thread. Could there be an /instruct command like /add that adds those files as system prompts instead of user input? 

Saved conversation threads could be used as Conversation Templates that are pre-configured, parameterized, and start private conversation threads that may or may not be ignored and checked into source code control. 

Conversation Templates could included pre-configured sets of files, wildcards, or dynamic procedural selections (like dependencies on .h files from selections of .c files, so a conversation about documentation could include all the header files, and a conversation about user interface could include all of the header files and all of the user interface .c files, and user interface api documentation). 

Selecting files per thread could be partially accomplished by threads having their own .alderignore files (including white lists) layered on top of the global repo wide alder white list. But procedure file selection by running shell commands or scripts would also be powerful. Also save and restore named sets of selected files on a per-conversation basis. So three layers of file name globbing + ignoring: repo, conversation thread, named file list. 

This enhancement would not only make it easier to manage multiple development streams within a single repository but also align Aider with more complex development workflows where multitasking across different components is necessary.

I would also love a "/foreach [list of files] [instructions]" command whose behavior could be specialized in each conversation. 

Thank you for considering this feature. I believe it could significantly enhance the practicality of Aider in more complex projects. I look forward to your insights and hopefully seeing this capability in a future release!

I am excited about the potential for this feature and how it could improve Aider!

System Info:

Aider version: v0.21.2-dev
Model being used: gpt-4-0613
Operating environment: Mac

issues.title: Clash between Aider's default fence and markdown's fenced code blocks
issues.body:
### Issue

Both aider and markdown fences use ```, so aider struggles with generated markdown documentation that has code blocks. This could indicate that making the fence parametrizable could help walkaround this issue or similar clashes in the future.

My current workaround is to generate asciidoc. But there's a lot of markdown in the wild so we're often stuck with that as input in legacy repos.

PS: love the tool, thanks!

### Version and model info

Aider: v0.43.4
Model: DeepSeek-Coder-V2

issues.title: Add support for `uv`?
issues.body:
### Issue

The [`uv`](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/) Python package manager is rapidly growing in popularity. Aider works pretty well out of the box with it (I use `uv tool install aider-chat`), however certain functions I think could work a bit better if Aider had "an awareness" of uv being used, for example prompts to upgrade fail. Also execution of resulting generated python code require a prefix of `uv run file.py`, instead of `python file.py`, unless one creates an alias. 

I do realise `uv` seems to break some conventions with regard to how Python files are called conventionally (by requiring a `uv` prefix, even for compatible operations such as `pip install` becomes `uv pip install` etc.) and this may not be something that the Aider maintainers may wish to support explicitly yet.

### Version and model info

Aider v0.62.0

issues.title: Vertex AI models can't use the weak or editor models?
issues.body:
### Issue

Using the Vertex AI provider/platform/API, we've been getting this series of errors forever, and I think it's causing fallback to the "big expensive" model for every operation, which is kinda burning through our free credits really fast (and it's slower, etc).

Usage:

```bash
VERTEXAI_PROJECT=XXX VERTEXAI_LOCATION=us-central1 aider --no-gitignore --no-attribute-author --no-attribute-committer --model vertex_ai/gemini-2.5-pro-preview-05-06
```

The `litellm.BadRequestError` shows up on every operation:

```
Applied edit to TODO.md
litellm.BadRequestError: LLM Provider NOT provided. Pass in the LLM provider you are trying to call. You passed model=vertex_ai-language-models/gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
 Pass model as E.g. For 'Huggingface' inference endpoints pass in `completion(model='huggingface/starcoder',..)` Learn more: https://docs.litellm.ai/docs/providers
```

Aider suggests this fix to aider and it appears to work for me. Feel free to add it back (I don't know if this is actually the best/correct place for this fix or if it should be fixed at the provider/model name creation elsewhere):


## Session

Okay, I will modify aider/models.py to normalize the Vertex AI model names. The change involves checking if the model name contains "-language-models/" and starts with   
vertex_ai, and if so, replacing "-language-models/" with / to ensure LiteLLM can correctly parse the provider. This normalization will happen in the Model class          
constructor.                                                                                                                                                              

Here is the SEARCH/REPLACE block:                                                                                                                                         

```haskell
aider/models.py                                                                                                                                                           
<<<<<<< SEARCH                                                                                                                                                            
        # Map any alias to its canonical name                                                                                                                             
        model = MODEL_ALIASES.get(model, model)                                                                                                                           
                                                                                                                                                                          
        self.name = model                                                                                                                                                 
=======                                                                                                                                                                   
        # Map any alias to its canonical name                                                                                                                             
        model = MODEL_ALIASES.get(model, model)                                                                                                                           
                                                                                                                                                                          
        # Normalize Vertex AI model names that include "-language-models/"                                                                                                
        if model.startswith("vertex_ai") and "-language-models/" in model:                                                                                                
            model = model.replace("-language-models/", "/", 1)                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                          
        self.name = model                                                                                                                                                 
>>>>>>> REPLACE
```



### Version and model info (with the above fix)

Main model: vertex_ai/gemini-2.5-pro-preview-05-06 with diff-fenced edit format
Weak model: vertex_ai/gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17
Repo-map: using 4096 tokens, auto refresh
```

### Version and model info (without the above fix)

issues.title: Allow the LLM to rename/move files/directories and run other shell commands
issues.body:
Is there any plan to make aider capable of performing more of the local file maintenance tasks required during development, of moving and renaming files and folders?

Or is this the kind of thing best left to a layer like langgraph or autogen with tools that wrap around aider?

RIght now my experiences go something like this, and sometimes crash when I ask it to move a file.
```
$ aider DESIGN.md
Aider v0.27.0
Model: gpt-4-1106-preview using udiff edit format
Git repo: ..\..\..\.git with 32 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens
Added filesystem\find\up\DESIGN.md to the chat.
Use /help to see in-chat commands, run with --help to see cmd line args
Note: in-chat filenames are always relative to the git working dir, not the current working dir.
Cur working dir: C:\Users\victorb\code\ai-sdlc\filesystem\find\up
Git working dir: C:\Users\victorb\code\ai-sdlc
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
filesystem\find\up\DESIGN.md
> Please write a find-up.sh file in the versions\0.2 folder, according to the features in DESIGN.md

This diff represents the creation of a new file `find-up.sh` in the `versions/0.2` directory. The script is a basic implementation of the `find-up` tool as described in the DESIGN.md document. It includes parsing of the new upward search flags, a function to perform the upward search, and the main logic to start the search from the current directory or a provided path.

```
```

Allow creation of new file versions/0.2/find-up.sh? y
Applied edit to versions/0.2/find-up.sh
Commit 24a88f8 aider: Create find-up.sh script for upward search functionality in versions/0.2 folder.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
versions\0.2\find-up.sh filesystem\find\up\DESIGN.md
> Can you move the versions tree from the root to `filesystem\find\up\

To move the `versions` tree from the root to `filesystem/find/up/`, you would typically use file system commands like `mv` in a Unix-like environment. However, since you're asking for a diff, I will provide you with a representation of what the changes would look like in a diff format. Please note that actual moving of directories and files is not something that can be represented in a diff because diffs show changes to file contents, not file system operations.

If you were to apply this change in a real environment, you would execute a command like this:
```
```sh
mv versions filesystem/find/up/
```
```
However, for the sake of this exercise, here's a representation of what the diff might look like if we were to "move" the contents of the `find-up.sh` script:
```
```diff
--- versions/0.2/find-up.sh
+++ filesystem/find/up/versions/0.2/find-up.sh
@@ ... @@
 # The contents of the file would remain unchanged, but the file's path is updated.
 # No actual content diff is provided since the file itself is not being modified, only moved.
```
```
Please execute the appropriate file system command to move the directory as diffs cannot perform such operations.
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
versions\0.2\find-up.sh filesystem\find\up\DESIGN.md
>
```

As a temporary workaround it is possible to use git global configuration to keep git clean. 
Global `.gitconfig`:
```
[core]
        excludesFile = ~/.gitignore_global
```
`~/.gitignore_global`:
```
.aider.tags.cache.v3
.aider.tags.cache.v4
.aider.chat.history.md
.aider.input.history
```
This will i

There is however no `AIDER_CCACHE_FILE` to define a custom location for `.aider.tags.cache.v4`.

issues.title: Aider project status in regards to PRs?
issues.body:
I hate to ask, but I'd really be interested in some clarification on what the status of the Aider project is.

It's clear updates are still being made, but they're mostly just small config updates for new models. An increasing amount of important PRs have a [Priority](https://github.com/Aider-AI/aider/pulls?q=is%3Apr%20is%3Aopen%20label%3Apriority) label (20, as of this post), but no direct feedback or indication of movement.

PRs like [MCP](https://github.com/Aider-AI/aider/pull/3937) are, in my opinion, critical.
Non-priority PRs like [map-tags-cache-dir Config](https://github.com/Aider-AI/aider/pull/3401) would be nice to have, but feel like they're going to go unnoticed.

This is not intended to be demanding, but just a request for information.

issues.title: Playwright installation for aider-chat via uv tool fails
issues.body:
### Issue

In my environment, attempting to install the latest `aider-chat` package through `uv` on macOS with Python 3.12 results in errors that prevent Playwright from being initialized. 

I ran the command

```bash
uv tool install --force --python python3.12 aider-chat
```

and was prompted to install Playwright. After confirming with “Yes,” the installer tried to execute:

```bash
/Users/matt/.local/share/uv/tools/aider-chat/bin/python -m pip install --upgrade --upgrade-strategy only-if-needed "aider-chat[playwright]"
```

This spawned the error message `“/Users/matt/.local/share/uv/tools/aider-chat/bin/python: No module named pip,”`




### Version and model info

**Environment**
• macOS (Apple Silicon)
• Python 3.12 
• uv tool version: 0.7.9
• aider-chat version: 0.84.0

```
python -m pip install uv  # If you need to install uv

```

https://aider.chat/docs/install.html

Recording, press ENTER when done... 6.6sec ██████████

issues.title: Config file location should follow "modern" specifications
issues.body:
Writing dotfiles into the root of user's home dir is not really a thing anymore.

For linux, there's the XDG base directory specification. This would make the location by default something like `~/.config/aider/config.yml`.  See https://gist.github.com/roalcantara/107ba66dfa3b9d023ac9329e639bc58c#file-xdg-cheat-sheet-md

On a mac `~/.config` is probably better for a terminal app than going to the "correct" `~/Library/Application Support/aider/config.yaml`. Tools like git, github copilot, gh cli, shells, neovim and many others use it or at least will make a symlink from there to Library.

On windows `%APPDATA%\Aider\config.yaml` is probably good.
issues.author: kke

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and reporting this issue.

FYI, you can also store the aider config yaml file in the root of your git working directory.

comments.author: harleypig
comments.body: The input and chat history and tag files should also be stored in (I think) `$XDG_CACHE_HOME/aider/{repo-name}`

comments.author: FelixLisczyk
comments.body: I've moved the configuration file to `~/.config/aider/config.yml` and created a symlink using `ln -s ~/.config/aider/config.yml ~/.aider.conf.yml`. Everything seems to be working fine so far. (aider 0.70.0 on macOS 15.2)

comments.author: harleypig
comments.body:
I have slightly different configs for some different repos, so allowing only a global config would be problematic for me.

Allowing for `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/aider/{repo-name}/config.yml` and/or `GIT_TOP_LEVEL/.aider.conf.yml` would be preferable to me.

comments.author: jchilders
comments.body:
I would like to add my voice to this request here, for all *nix variants. I use Darwin and would like to see this as well.

1. Configuration loaded from `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/aider/config.yml`, falling back to the other locations if not present.
2. Cached data stored in `$XDG_CACHE_HOME/aider`

Ref

When using llama-swap for example:

The POST path no longer includes additional basepath routes:

.aider.conf.yml:
```
openai-api-base: http://192.168.5.144:8012/v1
```

This base has a '/v1' which should be sent to the endpoint, however it is now getting stripped.


Expected llama-swap output Log (for aider-chat==0.82.2) shows correct '/v1' in POST path
```
INFO] Request 192.168.5.142 "POST /v1/chat/completions HTTP/1.1" 200 60298 "OpenAI/Python 1.73.0" 56.987908917s
```

Observed llama-swap output Log (for aider-chat > 0.82.2) shows request no longer honours the openai-api-base correctly: ('/v1' no longer getting sent)
```
[INFO] Request 192.168.5.142 "POST /chat/completions HTTP/1.1" 404 -1 "OpenAI/Python 1.75.0" 16.917µs
```

This causes aider to recieve a 404 error on the API request for any input:

litellm.NotFoundError: NotFoundError: OpenAIException - 404 page not found

issues.title: Command-Specific Model Selection
issues.body:
# Command-Specific Model Selection for Aider

## Overview
This feature request proposes enhancing Aider's model selection capabilities to provide more granular control over which AI models are used for specific commands or operations.

## Background
Aider currently supports three tiers of models:
- Main model (set via `--model` or `/model` command)
- Editor model (set via `--editor-model`, typically auto-selected based on main model)
- Weak model (set via `--weak-model`, used for commit messages and history summarization)

While this provides general-purpose model selection, users currently cannot associate specific commands with particular models, requiring either frequent model switching or compromising on model selection.

## Problem Statement
Users need the ability to associate specific AI models with particular commands or macros to optimize their workflow. The current general-purpose model selection creates friction when users need different models for different tasks within the same session.

For example, a user might want to:
- Use Claude 3.7 Sonnet for code generation
- Use DeepSeek for troubleshooting
- Use a lightweight (and fast) model for simple revisions

Currently, this requires manually switching models with the `/model` command before each operation, which disrupts workflow efficiency.

## Proposed Solution
Implement command-specific model selection with the following features:

### 1. Command-Model Association
- Add ability to specify which AI model to use for specific commands or macros
- Support different models for different command types within the same session
- Maintain the existing general-purpose model selection capability

### 2. Model Switching Improvements
- Allow users to switch between different models for the same command type as needed
- Support dynamic model switching during active sessions without requiring restart

### 3. Operation Concept
#### New Command Syntax
```
/with <model_name> <command> [arguments]
```
Example:
```
/with deepseek ask Why is this so slow?
/with sonnet code "Optimize the search algorithm"
/with o3-mini fix spelling errors
```
Using `/with` with no arguments will tie the model (or model alias) with the given command for the rest of the session.

issues.title: aider uses system Python instead of activated environment’s Python
issues.body:
### Issue

I installed `aider-chat` in a Conda environment, but when I run `aider`, it appears to be using the system Python instead of the Python from the activated environment.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
   ```bash
   conda create -y -n aider-env python=3.11
   conda activate aider-env
   pip install aider-chat
   ```

`which aider` and `which python` looks as expected.

Then:

   ```bash
   aider
   /run which python
   ```
   Output unexpectedly shows that `aider` is using the system Python rather than the one from the Conda environment: `/opt/miniconda3/bin/python`

This makes aider unusable since I get a bunch of `ImportError` when I try to `/run` anything.

**Expected Behavior:**  
`aider` should use the Python from the activated Conda environment instead of the system Python.

**Actual Behavior:**  
`aider` uses the system Python even though it was installed in the activated Conda environment.



### Version and model info

- Aider v0.74.3
- OS: macOS 15.3.1
- Python version inside Conda: Python 3.11.11
- System Python version: Python 3.12.2
issues.author: crypdick

comments.author: sabagithub
comments.body: I experience this in Aider v0.75.3 too, using miniconda. Whether it tries to run, or it tries to install, it uses the system version of Python/pip, not the miniconda environment in which I use Aider in. I'm in Linux (EndeavorOS)

comments.author: leszekhanusz
comments.body:
I would like also to be able to run commands in a specific Python environment.

For now the only way I found is to activate the env for each command, which is annoying of course:

```
/run conda activate myenv && python ...
```

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

This usually happens if you have something in your bashrc scripts that messes with the Python/conda environment. 

Aider launches /run commands with the same environment it was launched with.

comments.author: leszekhanusz
comments.body:
I can confirm that if I comment out the "conda initialize" section of my `~/.bashrc`, aider will stay in the current Python env and everything is working as it should.

Is there a way to know in the .bashrc file that it is aider which is running the shell? With an environment variable set or somethi

comments.author: leszekhanusz
comments.body:
One way to solve this problem is to use an environment variable to indicate when conda initialize has been done and not do it again if it has been done already.

In your `~/.bashrc`:

```
if [ -z "$CONDA_SETUP_DONE" ]; then

    ...put your conda initialize code here

fi
export CONDA_SETUP_DONE=1
``

issues.title: System message configuration issue
issues.body:
### Issue

# Aider Bug Report: System Message Configuration Issues

## Description
Multiple attempts to configure aider's system message have failed across different approaches. The configuration appears to be problematic with both YAML configuration and command-line arguments, suggesting a deeper issue with how system messages are handled.

## Summary of Issues
1. YAML configuration treats system message as a filename
2. Command-line argument for system message is not recognized
3. No clear documentation on the correct way to configure system messages
4. Error messages are not helpful in identifying the correct configuration method

## Steps to Reproduce
### Attempt 1 - YAML Configuration with Inline Message
1. Add to aider.conf.yml:
```yaml
system-message: "You are a pair programmer..."
```
Result: File name too long error

### Attempt 2 - YAML with Different Key Format
1. Try different key formats in aider.conf.yml:
```yaml
system_message: "..."
system-message: "..."
```
Result: Same file name too long error

### Attempt 3 - External File Reference in YAML
1. Create system message file (aider.system.txt)
2. Reference in aider.conf.yml:
```yaml
system-message-file: aider.system.txt
```
Result: Configuration not recognized

### Attempt 4 - Direct File Path in YAML
1. Update aider.conf.yml:
```yaml
system-message: /home/tom/git/dotfiles/aider.system.txt
```
Result: Treated as literal message text

### Attempt 5 - Command Line Argument
1. Create a system message file (aider.system.txt) with the desired prompt
2. Create an arguments file (aider.args) containing: `--system-message=/path/to/aider.system.txt`
3. Run aider with: `aider $(cat aider.args)`

## Current Behavior
1. When using YAML configuration with inline message:
```
OSError: [Errno 36] File name too long: 'You are a pair programmer...'
```

2. When using command line argument:
```
aider: error: unrecognized arguments: --system-message=/home/tom/git/dotfiles/aider.system.txt
```

3. When using system-message-file in YAML:
```
Configuration key 'system-message-file' not recognized
```

4. Full help output shows no system message configuration options:
```
usage: aider [-h] [--openai-api-key OPENAI_API_KEY]
             [--anthropic-api-key ANTHROPIC_API_KEY] [--model MODEL] [--opus]
             [--sonnet] [--haiku] [--4] [--4o] [--mini] [--4-turbo]
             ...
```

## Expected Behavior
Aider should accept the system message from the specified file and use it to configure the AI assistant's behavior.

## Environment
- OS: Linux 5.15.0-126-generic (64bit)
- Shell: /bin/bash
- Aider version: v0.65.1
- Main model: claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022

## Configuration Files and Attempts

### aider.conf.yml attempts:
1. Initial attempt:
```yaml
model: sonnet
editor: vim
analytics: true
analytics-log: analytics.log
cache-prompts: true
cache-keepalive-pings: 1
max-chat-history-tokens: 10000
system-message: "You are a pair programmer..."
```

2. File reference attempt:
```yaml
system-message: /home/tom/git/dotfiles/aider.system.txt
```

3. Alternative key attempt:
```yaml
system_message: "You are a pair programmer..."
```

### aider.system.txt:
Contains the complete system message:
```
You are a pair programmer that responds to natural language requests...
[Full message content]
```

### aider.args:
Command line argument attempt:
```
--system-message=/home/tom/git/dotfiles/aider.system.txt
```

### Execution Methods Tried:
1. Direct aider execution: `aider`
2. With config file: `aider -c aider.conf.yml`
3. With args file: `aider $(cat aider.args)`
4. Combined: `aider -c aider.conf.yml $(cat aider.args)`


### Version and model info


Aider v0.65.1
Main model: claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022 with diff edit format, prompt cache, infinite
output
Weak model: claude-3-5-haiku-20241022
Git repo: none
Repo-map: disabled
Added dotfiles/aider.args to the chat.
Added dotfiles/aider.conf.yml to the chat.
Added dotfiles/aider.system.txt to the chat.

Command Line Args:   --sonnet --vim --analytics --analytics-log analytics.log 
--cache-prompts --cache-keepalive-pings 1 --max-chat-history-tokens 10000

Environment Variables:

  ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: ...egAA

Defaults:

issues.title: Feature Request: Adding multiple repos to chat
issues.body:
With the addition of the new 128k model, it would be nice to have the option to add multiple repos to the chat so that we can compare them and add/modify functions from one to the other.

Also, a bit of a side note - it would be very nice to add a "/add all <repo name>" command, that just adds every single file from the repo to the chat or something like that to make the process easier, as it much easier now to just add every single file instead of relying on the repo map, since you dont even get close to the max tokens most of the time.

You should be able to do `/add *` to add an entire repo.

issues.title: Add per file type test/lint option suppot
issues.body:
Currently I've implemented custom script that sit in front of my raw lint/typecheck/test commands, because otherwise I have to reconfigure my aider for every project, there's no way to avoid a lot of false positive failures (e.g. Aider trying to typecheck/lint README.md), and there's no clean way to support multiple languages in a single project.

Ideally there would be syntax support in the config along the likes of:

```yml
lint-cmd:
    - "*.py": 
         - ruff
         - mypy
    - "*.ts":
        - bun typecheck
        - bun lint
    - ".github/workflows/*.yml"
        - actlint
    ...
```
This would go a long way towards reducing the configuration burden of Aider and enabling a better agentic workflow, since currently the number one thing I have to do that breaks the agentic loop is control what gets added to the context due to aider not being smart about which files get checked which ways.

issues.title: Proposal: Compact code modification format
issues.body:
**Proposal: A New Compact Unified Syntax for Efficient and Precise Code Modifications**

Hello Aider community! I'd like to address some issues with our current code modification system and propose a new, more efficient, and precise solution. Let's start by examining the problems we're facing:

**Current Issues:**

1. High Token Consumption:
   - Our current search/replace blocks often contain large portions of code, even when modifying small sections.
   - These tokens are generated by the model, which is costly.
   - Worse yet, these large blocks are resent with each request as part of the conversation, compounding the cost throughout the entire chat session.

2. Error-Prone Matching:
   - The current system requires an exact match in the search block.
   - Even minor differences in whitespace or formatting can cause the modification to fail.

3. Context Pollution:
   - Large search/replace blocks clutter the chat context.
   - This can negatively impact the model's performance and lead to confusion in longer sessions.


These issues not only affect the efficiency and reliability of our system but also significantly increase the cost of using Aider, especially for larger projects or longer sessions.

**Proposed Solution: Unified Code Modification Syntax**

To address these problems, I propose a new, unified syntax for all code modifications. This syntax is designed to be intuitive, flexible, efficient, and capable of handling multi-file projects with precision.

**The New Syntax:**
```
@file(path/to/file.ext)@location:operation
content
```

Where:
- `file(path/to/file.ext)` specifies the target file
- `location` specifies where in the code we want to make changes
- `operation` specifies what we want to do (`search`, `replace`, `add`, or `delete`)
- `content` is the relevant text for the operation

**Location Specifiers:**
- Code elements: `function`, `struct`, `method`, `var`, `const`, `import`
- Text matching: `text` (for string-based search and replace)
- File-level operations: Omit the second `@location` for file-level operations

**Operations:**
- `search`: Identify a section of code (used with `text` location)
- `replace`: Replace the specified code element or matched text
- `add`: Insert new code at the specified location
- `delete`: Remove the specified code element

**Positioning Modifiers:**
For `add` operations, you can use `.end`, `.after`, or `.before` to specify the exact insertion point.

**Examples:**

1. Replace a function in a specific file:
```
@file(src/main.go)@function(calculateTotal):replace
func calculateTotal(items []Item) float64 {
    total := 0.0
    for _, item := range items {
        total += item.Price * float64(item.Quantity)
    }
    return total
}
```

2. Traditional search and replace in a file:
```
@file(src/main.go)@text:search
fmt.Println("Hello, World!")
@file(src/main.go)@text:replace
fmt.Println("Hello, Aider!")
```

3. Add a method to a struct in a specific file:
```
@file(src/models/user.go)@struct(User).end:add
func (u *User) IsAdmin() bool {
    return u.Role == "admin"
}
```

4. Delete a variable declaration from a specific file:
```
@file(src/config/app.go)@var(MaxConnections):delete
```

5. Replace the entire contents of a file:
```
@file(src/main.go):replace
package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

func main() {
    fmt.Println("Hello, Aider!")
}
```

**Key Benefits:**

1. Reduced Token Usage: By precisely targeting code elements, we significantly reduce the number of tokens needed for most operations.
2. Improved Accuracy: Using tree-sitter for parsing allows for more accurate code element identification, reducing errors.
3. Cleaner Context: Smaller, more precise modification blocks keep the chat context cleaner.
5. Intuitive and Consistent: The syntax is easy to understand and use, with a consistent structure across all operations.
6. Backward Compatible: Supports traditional string-based search and replace for familiarity and edge cases.

**Implementation:**

The system will use a combination of tree-sitter for precise code parsing and string matching for backward compatibility:

1. Parse the `@file(path)@location:operation` syntax.
2. Identify the target file based on the provided path.
3. For code element locations, use tree-sitter to locate the specified element within the file.
4. For `@text` locations, perform string matching within the specified file.
5. Apply the operation (`search`, `replace`, `add`, `delete`) at the correct position in the correct file.
6. If we fail to find the block using symbol search we can retry using the search/replace as a fallback.

**Potential Challenges:**

1. Implementing tree-sitter support for multiple languages.
2. Handling complex nested structures accurately.
3. Balancing the precision of tree-sitter parsing with the flexibility of string matching.
4. Ensuring consistent behavior across different programming languages.
5. Maintaining code formatting and style during modifications.
7. Handling relative vs. absolute file paths.
8. Ensuring file paths are valid and accessible.

issues.title: Consider scanning for search blocks ignoring whitespace
issues.body:
I've seen Claude 3 Opus reformat code in search blocks - the code itself is identical except for formatting. Then the block fails to apply. It'd be good to scan for search blocks without paying attention to whitespace.

Example failed block:

```
 <<<<<<< SEARCH
     @CommandLine.Option(names = ["--disable-email-for-testing"], required = false, description = ["Whether to disable email sending. Only to be used for
 testing."])
     var disableEmail = false
 =======
     @CommandLine.Option(names = ["--disable-email-for-testing"], required = false, description = ["Whether to disable email sending. Only to be used for
 testing."])
     var disableEmail = false

     @CommandLine.Option(names = ["--keystore"], required = false, description = ["Path to the keystore file for SSL"])
     var keystorePath: Path? = null

     @CommandLine.Option(names = ["--keystore-password"], required = false, description = ["Password for the keystore file"])
     var keystorePassword: String? = null
 >>>>>>> REPLACE
```

Example working block:

```
 <<<<<<< SEARCH
     @CommandLine.Option(
         names = ["--disable-email-for-testing"],
         required = false,
         description = ["Whether to disable email sending. Only to be used for testing."]
     )
     var disableEmail = false
 =======
     @CommandLine.Option(
         names = ["--disable-email-for-testing"],
         required = false,
         description = ["Whether to disable email sending. Only to be used for testing."]
     )
     var disableEmail = false

     @CommandLine.Option(names = ["--keystore"], required = false, description = ["Path to the keystore file for SSL"])
     var keystorePath: Path? = null

     @CommandLine.Option(names = ["--keystore-password"], required = false, description = ["Password for the keystore file"])
     var keystorePassword: String? = null
 >>>>>>> REPLACE
```

I wouldn't have cared if it reformatted that to be one line, in the end.
issues.author: mikehearn

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body: This is a new thing, I've not seen other models full on reformat the code.

comments.body:
I have found it happen a lot of LLaMa 3.3 70B and LLaMa 3.1 family models.

I even tried instructing the LLM to indent it twice to match the rest of the indentation. But it's a hit or miss. I assume it's not because LLM "reformats" the code but because function is too large and only an inner block (

issues.title: Inconsistent behavior when invoking Bedrock LLMs
issues.body:
### Issue

Hello. When accessing the cross region inference models in AWS Bedrock i get inconsistent operations depending on the model invoked. When using any model but us.anthropic.claude-3-opus-20240229-v1:0 aider returns an error after i submit the first prompt. 

Error message: litellm.APIConnectionError: BedrockException - b'{"message":"You don\'t have access to the model with the specified model ID."}'

 For context:

- AWS SSO auth (confirmed auth does work).
- I have access to all models called in bedrock (confirmed with CLI invocation).
- analytics log for working model (claude-3-opus) - {"event": "message_send", "properties": {"main_model": "us.anthropic.claude-3-opus-20240229-v1:0", "weak_model": "us.anthropic.claude-3-opus-20240229-v1:0", "editor_model": "us.anthropic.claude-3-opus-20240229-v1:0", "edit_format": "diff", "prompt_tokens": 3147, "completion_tokens": 332, "total_tokens": 3479, "cost": 0.072105, "total_cost": 0.173115}, "user_id": "[REMOVED]", "time": 1742560429}

- analytics log for nonfunctional example (claude-3-7-sonnet) - {"event": "cli session", "properties": {"main_model": "us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0", "weak_model": "us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0", "editor_model": "us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0", "edit_format": "whole"}, "user_id": "[REMOVED]", "time": 1742560027}

I noticed that the edit format is different between the two (whole vs diff). I added an --edit-format diff flag to the command prompt and the 3-7 model maintained the "whole" setting (I am not sure if that is expected behavior). I also changed Opus to "whole" and it functioned properly so that probably is not related to the initial problem raised.

### Version and model info

aider --version = aider 0.77.1
us.anthropic.claude-3-opus-20240229-v1:0 
us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0

terminal invocation: 

aider --model us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0  

aider --model us.anthropic.claude-3-opus-20240229-v1:0
issues.author: abuakeel

comments.author: abuakeel
comments.body: Further comments. I checked the Cloudtrail logs for my AWS account. The opus calls are hitting the AWS endpoint. None of the 3.7 Sonnet calls are. So the calls are failing before they reach AWS.

comments.author: arvo95
comments.body: Having the same issue with Claude 3.5 v1 in Paris region. AWS CLI says I have access with my credentials, but errors out with Aider. This probably is an issue with the Aider dependency LiteLLM. Maybe should bump up the version? They recently had a lot of fixes for Bedrock specifically.

comments.author: arvo95
comments.body: Okay, it seems like I've figured out what the problem is. The LiteLLM usage slightly differs from the information in the Aider docs. To determine your region, it uses AWS_REGION_NAME environ and not AWS_DEFAULT_REGION - the one that AWS CLI actually uses. So by default LiteLLM sends the request to u

comments.author: abuakeel
comments.body: I ended up identifying the issue. It wasn't the AWS_REGION_NAME env variable export, but it was related. Since I am using the multi-region endpoints, it does mean i have to have access to the models in all AWS regions in the US that support the endpoint. Users must have access to a model (say Sonnet

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Sorry, can someone confirm if we need to make changes to the aider docs for Bedrock? And if so, what change is needed?

https://aider.chat/docs/llms/bedrock.html

issues.title: Gemini 2.5 Pro needs weak model assignment
issues.body:
### Issue

Problem:
gemini/gemini-2.5-pro-exp-03-25 currently has no weak model defined, so it uses itself for commit messages. This
unnecessarily consumes its strict rate limits.

Why it matters:
Gemini's free tier has tight RPM/daily quotas. Using the main model for simple commits burns through these limits
faster.

Solution:
Assign a lighter weak model (like gemini-1.5-flash) in model-settings.yml to preserve the main model's quota.

### Version and model info

_No response_
issues.author: aboveaboutbelow

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

The fix is available in the main branch for gemini/ and openrouter/ providers. You can get it by installing the latest version from github:

```
aider --install-main-branch

# or...

python -m pip install --upgrade --upgrade-strategy only-if-needed git

>         "input_cost_per_token": 0,> 
>         "litellm_provider": "openai",> 
>         "max_input_tokens": 90000,> 
>         "max_output_tokens": 4096,> 
>         "max_tokens": 90000,>

> }>

> There's more model than one though. I run aider with this command:> 
> ```sh> 
> aider \> 
>   --model foobar-model \> 
>   --model-metadata-file ~/.cache/aider-model-metadata.json \>

> ```>

> Both versions report the same settings, relevant lines from `aider -v`:>

```
{

        "input_cost_per_token": 0,

        "litellm_provider": "openai",

        "max_inp

issues.title: Python 3.13 support
issues.body:
Aider must run with python 3.9 - 3.12. It won't run with python 3.13.

That said, there are very easy ways for python3.13 users to install aider. These methods will quickly and seamlessly install aider, python3.12 and all needed dependencies in an isolated environment.

## With aider-install

If you have any python 3.8+ including python 3.13, you can use aider-install to install aider, python3.12 and all needed dependencies in an isolated environment.

```bash
python -m pip install aider-install
aider-install
```



## One-liners

These one-liners will install aider, along with python 3.12 if needed. They are based on the [uv installers](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/).

#### Windows

```powershell
powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://aider.chat/install.ps1 | iex"
```

#### Mac & Linux

Use curl to download the script and execute it with sh:

```bash
curl -LsSf https://aider.chat/install.sh | sh
```

If your system doesn't have curl, you can use wget:

```bash
wget -qO- https://aider.chat/install.sh | sh
```


## Install with uv

You can install aider with uv:

```bash
python -m pip install uv  # If you need to install uv
uv tool install --force --python python3.12 aider-chat@latest
```

This will install uv using your existing python version 3.8-3.13, and use it to install aider. If needed, uv will automatically install a separate python 3.12 to use with aider.

Also see the [install docs](https://aider.chat/docs/install.html).

issues.title: Feature request - templates for aider
issues.body:
### Issue

Some inspiration could be taken from
https://github.com/simonw/llm by Simon Willison, his LLM tool allows the creation of plugins (#1814) . He also has a prompt template system that allows users to save prompt templates. This can be used to interesting effect, for example (note in this example I wrote it out in full without using a template for clarity):

```
#!/bin/sh
llm -s "Output the keystrokes required to achieve the following task in vim. Answer in as few words as possible. Print the keystrokes, then on a newline print a succinct explanation." -m claude-3.5-sonnet "$*"
```
I  alias that script to `vh` and then use it like this:

~$ vh copy line under cursor
>yy
>Yank (copy) the current line

I think that custom commands would be handy for aider, for example when using aider as interactive help for itself, the following command would be handy to check what's new in aider:

`/run git log --since="1 month ago" --pretty=format:"%h - %s" --grep="feature\|add\|new"`

it would be handy to save things like that, but they're probably not worthy of a plugin - therefore ability to save them as a template would be handy.

### Version and model info

_No response_

  - LITELLM_LOCAL_MODEL_COST_MAP='True'
```

Adding that to aider's config.yml drastically speeds up start-up

issues.title: aider not writing file contents to disk
issues.body:
### Issue

aider v0.70.0
Cmd: `aider --sonnet --verbose`

I noticed while running in verbose mode that aider was receiving responses containing *SEARCH/REPLACE* blocks, which were not being written to the filesystem even though they appear to be formatted correctly. Both times I saw this behavior, the LLM response didn't end until it asked to add another file in the chat. At that point, aider prompted me to add files to the chat but the edits were never written to disk.

Below is a snippet from the second time it happened to me.

```
ASSISTANT Ok, any changes I propose will be to those files.

USER Let's work on the chat command and chat panel files

USER I added these files to the chat: src/commands/chat.ts, src/panels/chatPanel.ts
...
...<omitted for brevity>
...
USER ONLY EVER RETURN CODE IN A *SEARCH/REPLACE BLOCK*!
USER 
USER Examples of when to suggest shell commands:
USER 
USER - If you changed a self-contained html file, suggest an OS-appropriate command to open a browser to view it to see the updated content.
USER - If you changed a CLI program, suggest the command to run it to see the new behavior.
USER - If you added a test, suggest how to run it with the testing tool used by the project.
USER - Suggest OS-appropriate commands to delete or rename files/directories, or other file system operations.
USER - If your code changes add new dependencies, suggest the command to install them.
USER - Etc.
USER 
I'll help implement the chat functionality based on the implementation plan. We'll need to:

1. Create the ChatPanel class to handle the UI
2. Implement the chat commands
3. Wire everything together

Here are the changes:

src/panels/chatPanel.ts
<source>typescript
<<<<<<< SEARCH
=======
import * as vscode from 'vscode'
import { LLMProvider } from '../providers/types'
import { Message } from '../providers/types'

export class ChatPanel {
    ...<omitted for brevity>
}
>>>>>>> REPLACE
</source>

src/commands/chat.ts
<source>typescript
<<<<<<< SEARCH
=======
import * as vscode from 'vscode'
import { LLMProvider } from '../providers/types'
import { ChatPanel } from '../panels/chatPanel'

export function registerChatCommands(
        context: vscode.ExtensionContext,
        provider: LLMProvider
) {
        let disposable = vscode.commands.registerCommand(
                'multi-llm-assistant.openChat',
                () => {
                        ChatPanel.createOrShow(provider)
                }
        )

        context.subscriptions.push(disposable)
}
>>>>>>> REPLACE
</source>

These changes implement:
1. A ChatPanel class that manages a webview-based chat interface
2. Basic chat UI with message history and input field
3. Command registration to open the chat panel
4. Message handling between the webview and extension

The chat interface supports:
- Sending messages with Send button or Enter key
- Scrollable message history
- Error handling for failed requests
- Persistent panel state

You'll need to add the command to package.json. Would you like me to help with that?
Tokens: 4.9k sent, 1.3k received. Cost: $0.03 message, $0.08 session.
Add package.json to the chat? (Y)es/(N)o/(D)on't ask again [Yes]:
```

### Version and model info

_No response_

This is intended behavior.

https://aider.chat/docs/faq.html#why-did-aider-ignorediscard-its-proposed-edits-after-it-asked-to-add-a-new-file-to-the-chat

issues.title: Linting error on file paths with `()[]` characters
issues.body: ### Issue In nextjs and other frontend frameworks, files can be named with `[]()` characters e.g. `src/(main)/product/[id]/page.tsx`. eslint fails to recognize these paths when you dont surround them with quotes. e.g. ```bash eslint src/(main)/product/[id]/page.tsx ``` it does not error when wrapping the filepath in quotes e.g. ```bash eslint "src/(main)/product/[id]/page.tsx" ``` is there a way to pass a "template" command for the `lint-cmd` option? something like: ```yaml lint-cmd: - javascript:eslint "" - typescript:eslint "" ``` o that the resulting command would wrap the filepath in quotes Here are some screenshots of the issue: ### Version and model info _No response_
issues.author: princejoogie

comments.author: princejoogie
comments.body: afaik thats default behavior for shells since it's used for globing, so being able to pass a "template" for the lint cmd would be nice

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
This should be fixed in the latest version. You can get it like this:

```
aider --upgrade

# or...

python -m pip install --upgrade --upgrade-strategy only-if-needed aider-chat
```

If you have a chance to try it, let me know if it works better for you.

issues.title: Aider tries to execute search/replace blocks in a terminal shell
issues.body:
### Issue

I've been having a lot of issues with diff and edit-diff lately.  Aider will try to make edits with search/replace blocks but they fail rapidly and there is no detail about why.   Ocassionally it will finish with one sad search/replace block in a different visual format and it will ask if I want the shell to execute it.  I mean actually execute the search/replace text.  I would guess that this area of aider is evolving quickly so this is mostly fyi and by the time anyone reads this it may already have been resolved.  Thank you.

aider 0.81.2
i've been bouncing around between models gemini pro2.5, claude 3.7, and gemini 2.0 flash.  I use both code and architect modes. I can't really isolated it to a particular model. I'll pay attention to see if it is related to a model and update this issue if it is.

issues.title: Documentation: how to install optional deps w/ uv (playwright, help, ...)
issues.body:
The docs suggest users install aider via `uv`, but don't explain how to install optional deps like `playwright`. If you write a URL into the prompt, aider suggests you install playwright, but in a completely different and unhelpful way, incompatible w/ `uv`.

I suggest describing how to do it in the documentation.

Anyway, I have a PR resolving this: #3351

issues.title: Proposal: Add `attribute-co-authored-by` Option to Fix Unexpected Author/Committer Modification
issues.body:
## Problem  

Currently, `aider` modifies author / committer name by appending `(aider)`, e.g., `John Doe (aider)`.
This behavior is non-standard, may break commit signature verification, and is generally unexpected for users.

Using Git's `Co-authored-by` trailer is a well-established alternative for attributing contributions without touching the user name.

A very similar issue already exists - #3270 (describing that GitHub will work better with such annotation), and Claude Code is also using `Co-authored-by` format (though, some want it to be disabled https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/617).

## Proposal  

Add `attribute-co-authored-by` option to `.aider.conf.yml`:  

```yaml
attribute-co-authored-by: true
```

Behavior:  
- If `true`:
  - Append `Co-authored-by: aider (<model>) <noreply@aider.dev>` to commit message
  - Disable behavior of other `attribute-` options, if they are not specified explicitly
- If `false` or unset:  
  - Rely on other `attribute-` options to keep the current behavior for backward compatibility

For context, currently available related options are:
```yaml
# Attribute aider code changes in the git author name (default: True)
attribute-author: true
# Attribute aider commits in the git committer name (default: True)
attribute-committer: true
# Prefix commit messages with 'aider: ' if aider authored the changes (default: False)
attribute-commit-message-author: false
# Prefix all commit messages with 'aider: ' (default: False)
attribute-commit-message-committer: false
```

Description of `attribute-author` option default value should be changed to mention relation with `attribute-co-authored-by`.

## Benefits  

- Respects user Git configuration  
- Compatible with commit signature verification  
- Aligns with Git conventions  
- Makes `aider` usage less intrusive in existing workflows  

## Notes  

Alternative: consider flipping the default (use `Co-authored-by` by default) in a future major release.

issues.body:
### Issue

I modified the HTML for an angular component, to remove a comment that I thought was not helpful. I saved the file but did not commit the change. 

Then I asked aider to make a change to that same html.  aider used the old (committed) version of the html file, not the version I just modified.  

aider came up with this diff initially: 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d6cb87c5-0871-400e-86bd-c0ad73dba0bb)

And that didn't work, so it had to try again, finally coming up with this diff:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/971bb2ab-5447-40ab-ab06-4907bd5d609d)

This worked, but... it took an extra cycle and maybe an extra 15-20 seconds.  Am I doing it wrong? Do I need to commit every change before asking aider to do anything else? 

Thanks.

```
Aider v0.81.2
Main model: gemini/gemini-2.5-pro-exp-03-25 with diff-fenced edit format
Weak model: gemini/gemini-2.0-flash
Git repo: .git with 72 files

Aider always uses the latest copy of the files from the filesystem, as of the moment you press ENTER to send your message. You do not need to commit for aider to pick up changes.

Are you sure you and your editor actually saved the edited file to disk?

comments.author: AM-I-Human
comments.body:
To solve this issue by adding the variables using set-env:
```
set-env:
  - REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE=/path/to/your/cacert.pem
  - SSL_CERT_FILE=/path/to/your/cacert.pem
``` 
This will not cause errors on models call, but it will be using the `/run command`  with `uv` or something that have TLS enabled

issues.title: 100% cpu freezing does not respond to ctrl c on latest release
issues.body:
### Issue

Process hangs at 100% CPU while rendering markdown/syntax highlighting. The process becomes unresponsive and requires force termination. This appears to be due to a pathological case in Pygments' lexer pattern matching.

Stack trace indicates issue is triggered during syntax highlighting in Rich/Pygments pipeline:
- Entry point: aider markdown rendering
- Through Rich markdown -> syntax highlighting
- Finally stuck in Pygments lexer processing

Steps to reproduce
1. Running standard aider chat interface
2. Process hangs during markdown/code rendering
3. CPU usage spikes to 100%
4. Process becomes unresponsive
5. Requires force termination via kill -6 (SIGABRT)

Stack trace
Most relevant section showing where process got stuck:
```
pythonCopyFile "/Users/stephensolka/.local/pipx/venvs/aider-chat/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pygments/lexer.py", line 712 in get_tokens_unprocessed
File "/Users/stephensolka/.local/pipx/venvs/aider-chat/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pygments/lexers/scripting.py", line 169 in get_tokens_unprocessed

issues.title: [FeatReq] Add a Tasklist to Aider
issues.body:
### Issue

Aider needs a task list. This will help the progress and keeping track of with the code changes we need.
The best would be taking the example from Github: we need just three things:  
- feature requests (aka TODO)
- bug reports (aka TOFIX)
- tasklist

The user should be able to create those with two new aider commands:  
  
**“/task feature <description>”** : add a feature request description
**“/task bug <description>”** : add a bug report
  
Also the AI should be able to create those entries by itself in the /ask mode if the user asks for new features, or if the user report a bug.

Those two kind of entries could also be imported from the github repo issues list, with a command like this:  
  
**“/github-sync _repo url_”**  

You should also be able to specify if you want just to sync the bugs and/or the features:  
  
**“/github-sync _repo url_ features bugs”**

When you need to have a overview of the project progress, you should be able to call a command like:  
  
**“/task list”**

...and getting a result like:  
  
**TASKLIST:**

| n | Description                                            | Reference URL                                      | Status         |
|---------|--------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|----------------|
| 1 | [❇️ Feat] Add user authentication feature                        | https://github.com/myproject/issues/45             | 📝 planned     |
| 2 | [🪲Bug] Fix crash on startup when configuration is missing     | https://github.com/myproject/issues/32             | ✅ solved      |
| 3 | [❇️ Feat] Implement dark mode for the application                |                                                   | 📝 planned     |
| 4 | [🪲Bug] Resolve memory leak in data processing module          | https://github.com/myproject/issues/19             | 🔄 in progress |
| 5 | [❇️ Feat] Add support for exporting data in CSV format           | https://github.com/myproject/issues/52             | 📝 planned     |
| 6 | [🪲Bug] Correct typo in user settings description              |                                                   | ✅ solved      |
| 7 | [❇️ Feat] Create an admin dashboard for monitoring activities    |                                                   | 📝 planned     |
| 8 | [🪲Bug] Address layout issues on mobile devices                | https://github.com/myproject/issues/27             |  📝 planned |
| 9 | [❇️ Feat] Integrate third-party API for weather updates          |                                                   | 📝 planned     |
| 10 | [🪲Bug] Fix broken link in the help documentation              |                                                   | ❌ wontfix     |

**Project Status Summary:**
- 📝 Planned: 6
- ✅ Solved: 2
- ❌ Wontfix: 1
- 🔄 In Progress: 1

**Write a task number and the new status (Example: “21 solved”). “n drop” to delete a task. C to clear all tasks:**  
**> 8 solved**   

In Aider help:
*You can show the tasklist with the command* **/task list**
*You can delete a task with the command* **/task drop _n_**
*You can change the status of a task with the command* **/task status _n_ _new-status_**
*You can create new bug report with the command* **/task bug _description_**
*You can create new feature request with the command* **/task feature _description_**  
*You can sync bug reports and feature requests with your Github repo with*   **/github-sync _URL_**
  

NOTE: The AI can create tasks, but only the user can change the status of a task. Until a task is not marked as solved the AI will try to complete it, starting with fixing bugs, and only when all bugs are fixed it will start adding new features. Of course the user can ask the AI to focus on a certain task number.

What do you think?





### Version and model info

_No response_

issues.title: Install fails because multidict 6.3.2 was yanked
issues.body:
### Issue

Installing via uv/mise currently fails with this error:

```
mise ERROR uv failed
  × No solution found when resolving dependencies:
  ╰─▶ Because multidict==6.3.2 was yanked (reason: Memory leak:
      https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/issues/1131#issuecomment-2787514071)
      and aider-chat==0.81.1 depends on multidict==6.3.2, we can conclude that
      aider-chat==0.81.1 cannot be used.
      And because you require aider-chat==0.81.1, we can conclude that your
      requirements are unsatisfiable.
mise ERROR failed to install pipx:aider-chat@0.81.1
mise ERROR uv exited with non-zero status: exit code 1
mise ERROR Run with --verbose or MISE_VERBOSE=1 for more information
```

Looks like this version was yanked just 2 days ago, see https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/issues/1131#issuecomment-2787514071

### Version and model info

Aider: 0.81.1
uv: 0.6.14
mise: 2025.4.0
issues.author: toupeira

comments.author: peedrr
comments.body:
`multidict` was yanked due to a memory leak.

Now resolved [as of multidict 6.4.0](https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/issues/1131) (or 6.4.1 - see final comment) 

~~@paul-gauthier - dep bump please! 🙏~~ See below.

comments.author: peedrr
comments.body: Digging a little deeper, `multidict` is a dependency of `yarl` and `aiohttp`. Both have merged dependency bumps ([`yarl`](https://github.com/aio-libs/yarl/pull/1503), [`aiohttp`](https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/pull/10720)) but neither have made it into a release yet. Guess we sit and wait.

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

If you want aider to use a specific model, you should specify it with `--model`, like:

```
aider --model sonnet
aider --model gemini
```

issues.title: REQ: Enhance repo-map to include heading docstrings
issues.body:
### Issue

One of the things I've been using aider for is to do a lot of the mundane documenting and detailing of code.  Not only is this helpful for humans, but it also makes it easier for the AI to understand the functions and interactions as the project grows and it makes updates and enhancements more accurate.

I was wondering whether it could be helpful to have an enhanced option of the repo map that, if there is a docstring that explains a function, it includes that information to help better guide the AI.  For example:

```
 def create_task(title: str, description: str, due_date: date, priority: int = 1) -> Task:
      """
      Purpose:
          Create a new task with the given details.
      Parameters:
          title (str): Non-empty string up to 200 characters.
          description (str): Optional, up to 1000 characters.
          due_date (date): Must be a future date.
          priority (int, optional): Between 1 and 5 (default is 1).
      Returns:
          Task: The newly created task object.
      Raises:
          ValidationError: If inputs fail validation.
      Notes:
          - Initializes task status to 'Not Started'.
          - Triggers notification to project managers.
      Sanity Checks:
          - Validate input lengths and ranges.
          - Ensure due_date is in the future.
      """
```



### Version and model info
Aider v0.59.1
Main model: claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620 with diff edit format, prompt cache, infinite output
Weak model: claude-3-haiku-20240307
Git repo: .git with 23 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens, files refresh

issues.title: Feature: Auto track loaded files
issues.body:
### Issue

There should be a switch that will track the loaded editable and read only files using the load and save cmds. It should probably sha1/sha256 the folder path and store in .local/.config on linux at-least as state.

This will mean if you exit or accidentally kill the editor you can stop needing to manually track everything or do anything awkward to get your context restored. Could apply to `/web` or other fragments too.

_No response_

issues.title: Is there an automated way to always try to fix the code after failed tests instead of `What's wrong? Fix` queries?
issues.body:
### Issue

I have `aider` break my tests often, and it would be so amazing if it could just follow up itself to failed tests to fix the code, instead of prompting me with `What's wrong? Fix` queries. Maybe with a configurable limit of, say 3, failed tests in succession to finally ask the user for help.

Maybe with a new setting `auto-test-fix: true` (or `auto-test-fix-limit: 3`) for `auto-test: true`?

What do you think? Cline behaves this way, and it often manages to fix the tests itself, which is great.

### Version and model info

Aider v0.78.0
Model: openrouter/deepseek/deepseek-chat:free with diff edit format, prompt cache, infinite output
Git repo: .git with 272 files
Repo-map: using 4096 tokens, auto refresh
Added memory-bank/techContext.md to the chat.
issues.author: Dima-369

comments.author: Dima-369

I think that might be a bug in the code. `cmd_run()` never returns anything, so `cmd_test()` also returns nothing, so `test_errors = self.commands.cmd_test(self.test_cmd)` is never filled, and the tests are never tried to be fixed automatically.

`cmd_run()` should return `msg` on errors, then it wo

issues.title: Repomap "falling back to memory cache" error due to breaking change in SQLite 3.49
issues.body:
### Issue

SQLite 3.49 breaks repomap disk caching feature ("falling back to memory cache"), poking deeper the actual problem is:

`SQLite Error: OperationalError: no such column: "size" - should this be a string literal in single-quotes?`

Forcing `sqlite=3.48.0` in python env solves the problem.

This is similar to: https://github.com/SciQLop/speasy/issues/197 and other recent reports like this.

issues.title: Undo prompt command
issues.body:
### Issue

Hi,

I'd like for there to exist an undo prompt command, in addition to the undo command that currently exists. I only use aider in no-auto-commit mode, as I like to view the changes in my editor and control the commits myself. In this workflow, the undo command currently in aider is of no use.

I often find myself in a situation where I write a prompt that doesn't do what I want, and I therefore want to revert it. This command would do exactly that, allowing me to write a different prompt, or maybe remove more prompts.

I can imagine it working like this:

command: /undo-prompt
result: Undoes all edits done by the last prompt, and resets the chat history to what it was before the last prompt was issued. Can be issued multiple times to gradually remove prompts until there are none left.


I hope this gets considered added!

Thanks

### Version and model info

_No response_
issues.author: Aeraxys

comments.author: sholub89
comments.body:
I would love to see this feature as well.
I believe very many developers use it with `--no-auto-commit` because we want to inspect the changes before committing them. Undoing the last change would be a super helpful feature if possible.

Yeah, imo that is the only way it makes sense to use this tool.

If it was up to me, this would be the default workflow and the command I described would be the default /undo command, as It's what I think most people would expect an undo command to do in a tool like this.

issues.title: [Bug] When prefill is used to continue for "infinite" output length, the thinking tokens should be included from the former request.
issues.body:
### Issue

Currently when the output length is filled and aider tries to continue with a prefill message, this error is hit:
```
litellm.BadRequestError: AnthropicException - 
b'{"type":"error","error":{"type":"invalid_request_error","message":"messages.3.content.0.typ
e: Expected `thinking` or `redacted_thinking`, but found `text`. When `thinking` is enabled, 
a final `assistant` message must start with a thinking block. We recommend you include 
thinking blocks from previous turns. To avoid this requirement, disable `thinking`. Please 
consult our documentation at 
https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/extended-thinking"}}'
```

Minimal/self-contained replication:
```sh
ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="add_api_key_here"
wget -O game.html https://gist.githubusercontent.com/josephrocca/819a14b7182312f6fda43999294ebfc0/raw/40c5924d7a5b522a6e60d5cfcac9bdbb091654f3/index.html
docker run -it -e ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=$ANTHROPIC_API_KEY --user $(id -u):$(id -g) --volume $(pwd):/app paulgauthier/aider-full:v0.82.0 --model claude-3-7-sonnet-latest --edit-format whole --thinking-tokens 32k --message "Fix bugs and add LOTS of improvements to this. Expand the scope of the game significantly and add heaps of new features." game.html
```

issues.author: josephrocca

issues.title: Enhancement: Only commit staged files if files have been staged.
issues.body:
### Issue

I appreciate Aider's commit messages; they often surpass Copilot's, which seems to have declined recently.

In my workflow, I stage the files I intend to commit, create a commit message for them, and then proceed to stage the next set of files. 

I'm considering using Aider's `/commit` feature for this process. However, Aider currently stages and commits all modified files.

This doesn't align with my method of working alongside Aider, where I prefer to commit only the staged files, not every changed file.

Additionally, I've observed that Aider overlooks new files during `/commit`. If `/commit` is designed to stage and commit all changes, excluding new files appears to be an oversight.

Finally, during refactors, I often end up with numerous uncommitted files. I need to segment these into several commits. Even if I wanted Aider to commit everything, I would encounter a "diff too large" error.

### Version and model info

Aider v0.43.4
Models: openrouter/anthropic/claude-3.5-sonnet with diff edit format, weak model gpt-3.5-turbo
Git repo: .git with 505 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens
VSCode terminal detected, pretty output has been disabled.
Use /help <question> to ask for help, run with --help to see cmd line args

I think it might be helpful to just apply the diffs from the first message before the file got added. I keep accidentally adding files which can be expensive and time consuming to fix, especially for large refactors

First, let's update the src/init.py file:                                                 

src/init.py                                                                               

                                                                                          
 <<<<<<< SEARCH

 =======                                                                                  
 # Make src a proper package

issues.author: tom-doerr

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body: This is intentional, to avoid hallucinations if the LLM was trying to apply edits before it was able to see a relevant file. Otherwise it may have guessed about the contents of that file, resulting in inappropriate changes.

comments.author: tom-doerr
comments.body: It does seem to also discard all changes to files that it has seen. At least with new models the changes to files that it have seen do not seem to contain hallucinations

issues.title: LiteLLM and model aliasing?
issues.body:
### Issue

I am using LiteLLM locally as a central (and cost management) proxy for multiple LLMs - as an example, I have OpenAI’s o3, Azure’s deepseek-r1, Anthropic’s Claude, etc., all available and accessible using a single key and a local OpenAI-compatible endpoint, which makes a lot of things much easier when switching tools (I use just the one URL and local key, and don’t have to remember or set up multiple endpoints/keys).

But when using aider, I haven’t been able to tell it that deepseek-r1 is actually “deepseek-r1-azure on this private OpenAI compatible endpoint with this key”, for instance. I think such an aliasing mechanism is needed for these setups (or, indeed, for any equivalent setups where developers have to go through a proxy).

Is there any simple way to do this? I’ve tried renaming the models on LiteLLM to match the “defaults”, and that sort of works for OpenAI models (because in that case I can tell it that gpt-4o on Azure is “normal” gpt-4o with a custom OpenAI endpoints), but it can’t really figure out how to use deepseek-r1 or Claude, and gets confused by there being an “OpenAI” endpoint, or about what context length is supported, etc. 

### Version and model info

_No response_

issues.title: FR: use litellm's langfuse callback (easy)
issues.body:
### Issue

Hi,

Longtime fan of aider, thanks a lot for creating it!

I use it a lot and am missing the fact that litellm's [langfuse](https://langfuse.com/) integration does not seem used by aider. It would really help me centralize costs, understand prompts etc.

The integration is [super easy](https://docs.litellm.ai/docs/observability/langfuse_integration), basically :

```python
import os
import litellm
if all(
    os.environ.get("LANGFUSE_PUBLIC_KEY", None),
    os.environ.get("LANGFUSE_SECRET_KEY", None),
    ):
    litellm.success_callback = ["langfuse"]
    litellm.failure_callback = ["langfuse"]
```

Alternatively you could look for "AIDER_LANGFUSE_PUBLIC_KEY" and if present rename it to "LANGFUSE_PUBLIC_KEY".

Also note that langfuse needs to be installed because litellm will then try to import it.

Can you consider adding it?

Thanks a lot!


PS: going the extra mile would be adding a "tags" : ["aider"] in the metadata of requests, as [described here](https://docs.litellm.ai/docs/observability/langfuse_integration)

### Version and model info

_No response_

issues.title: Configure Aider with custom models?
issues.body:
### Issue

I am not sure this is the right place to ask my question. I also made a [stackoverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/q/79517581/719276). Feel free to close this issue if it's not appropriate.

I would like to use [Aider](https://aider.chat/) with models hosted on [glhf.chat](https://glhf.chat/).

I use this configuration:

`~/aider.conf.yml`

```
openai-api-base: https://glhf.chat/api/openai/v1
openai-api-key: glhf_MY_SECRET_API_KEY
model-settings-file: ~/.aider.model.settings.yml
model: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1
weak-model: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3
editor-model: Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-32B-Instruct

```

`~/.aider.model.settings.yml`
```

- name: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3
  edit_format: diff
  use_repo_map: true
  reminder: sys
  examples_as_sys_msg: true
  extra_params:
    max_tokens: 8192
  caches_by_default: true

- name: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1
  edit_format: diff
  weak_model_name: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3
  use_repo_map: true
  examples_as_sys_msg: true
  extra_params:
    max_tokens: 8192
    include_reasoning: true
  caches_by_default: true
  editor_model_name: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3
  editor_edit_format: editor-diff

- name: Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-32B-Instruct
  edit_format: diff
  weak_model_name: Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-32B-Instruct
  use_repo_map: true
  editor_model_name: Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-32B-Instruct
  editor_edit_format: editor-diff

```

But when I start aider it says:

```
───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Warning for deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1: Unknown context window size and costs, using sane defaults.
Did you mean one of these?
- deepseek/deepseek-chat
- deepseek/deepseek-coder
Warning for deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3: Unknown context window size and costs, using sane defaults.
Did you mean one of these?
- deepseek/deepseek-chat
Warning for Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-32B-Instruct: Unknown context window size and costs, using sane defaults.
Did you mean one of these?
- openrouter/qwen/qwen-2.5-coder-32b-instruct
You can skip this check with --no-show-model-warnings

```
Why? How can I get rid of those warnings?

### Version and model info

Aider v0.77.1
Main model: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 with diff edit format, prompt cache
Weak model: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3
Git repo: .git with 12 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens, auto refresh
