```
{
  "openai/hf:deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1": {
    "max_tokens": 8192,
    "max_input_tokens": 128000,
    "max_output_tokens"

issues.title: Prompt caching broken in 0.72.1 for Claude in VertexAI
issues.body:
### Issue

I'm using Claude in VertexAI and the prompt caching was working fine with the following settings:
```
- name: vertex_ai/claude-3-5-sonnet-v2@20241022
  cache_control: true
  caches_by_default: false
  edit_format: diff
  examples_as_sys_msg: true
  streaming: true
  use_repo_map: true
  use_system_prompt: true
  use_temperature: true
```

After updating from 0.71.0 to 0.72.1, I'm getting this error

```
litellm.BadRequestError: VertexAIException BadRequestError - {"type":"error","error":{"type":"invalid_request_error","message":"Unexpected value(s) 
`prompt-caching-2024-07-31` for the `anthropic-beta` header. Please consult our documentation at docs.anthropic.com or try again without the header."}}
```

Downgrading to 0.71.0 made the caching work again

### Version and model info

Aider v0.72.1
Main model: vertex_ai/claude-3-5-sonnet-v2@20241022 with diff edit format, prompt cache, infinite output
Weak model: vertex_ai/gemini-1.5-flash-002
Git repo: .git with 64 files
Repo-map: using 4096 tokens, files refresh

{

/run git diff HEAD^
/add other-file.ext
Make that change to the other file
```

I'm not exactly sure if this is a problem with my terminal or something but the thing it's been like that since I started using aider a couple of months ago. This is the format used in either astro or vue.
So, the command:
```
/read-only src/pages/\[parameter\]/index.astro
```
it will throw the following error:
```
No matches found for: src/pages/[lang]/[i]/index.astro
```
And the command:
```
aider --read src/pages/\[parameter\]/index.astro
```
Will show the following:
```
Readonly: src/pages//index.astro 
```
the context is correctly passed to the LLM though.

### Version and model info

_No response_
issues.author: silgon

issues.title: [Security Issue] The aider gui feature can be accessed by anyone
issues.body:
### Issue

The aider gui feature can be accessed by anyone who has access to the internal network by
accessing the URL. The attacker is able to add or edit a file on the victim's machine and also view
the victim's chat history.

I think, we should start by default with localhost?

### Version and model info

_No response_
issues.author: brahmareddybattula

comments.author: brahmareddybattula
comments.body: @paul-gauthier any thoughts on this issue..? Can we start with localhost only.? thanks

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

If you wish you can always direct streamlit to use whatever host/port you prefer:

```
export STREAMLIT_SERVER_ADDRESS=localhost
export STREAMLIT_SERVER_PORT=8501
```

comments.author: brahmareddybattula
comments.body: thanks @paul-gauthier !!  as of now, how about having this as default "export STREAMLIT_SERVER_ADDRESS=localhost", so that users when they enable gui will be restricted.?

comments.author: santosha001
comments.body:
Hi @paul-gauthier 
The STREAMLIT_SERVER setting is configured at the user level. If a user does not explicitly set this value, their machine may be vulnerable since it can be accessed via the network URL. Ideally, the network URL should NOT be exposed and enabled by default to ensure proper security

issues.title: How to find out what lint command `aider` is running?
issues.body:
### Issue

As of the latest version, after editing a `config.fish` file, aider runs something that claims there's an error in the file, and then goes about fixing it.

```
Tokens: 15k sent, 719 received. Cost: $0.06 message, $0.28 session.
Applied edit to .config/fish/config.fish

# Fix any errors below, if possible.


## See relevant line below marked with █.

.config/fish/config.fish:
...⋮...
 131│if status --is-interactive
 132│
...⋮...
 487│    function __git_fzf_git_stash -d "fzf on git stashes"
...⋮...
 490│        git stash list --color=always \
 491│            # We seem to need delta explicitly, since git will write without using
 492│            # delta if it's not a tty.
 493█            | SHELL=fish fzf -m --ansi --no-sort \
 494│            --preview "git stash show -p (echo {} | rg '$pattern' -o) | delta" \
 495│            --bind=ctrl-p:"become(git stash pop (echo {} | rg '$pattern' -o) > /dev/tty)" \
 496│            | rg $pattern -o \
...⋮...

```

Here are the configs with `lint` in them:
```
  auto-lint:         True
  --lint-cmd:        []
  - auto_lint: True
  - lint: False
  - lint_cmd: []

```

How can I figure out what linter is being run? It happens to be wrong!

Thank you!

### Version and model info

Aider v0.77.0
Main model: anthropic/claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 with diff edit format, 31.2k think tokens, infinite output
Weak model: anthropic/claude-3-5-haiku-20241022
Git repo: .git with 43 files
Repo-map: using 4096 tokens, auto refresh
issues.author: max-sixty

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

It's probably running the built in tree-sitter parser to check syntax.

You can either turn off linting or set the linter for fish to be a no-op with `--lint-cmd "fish: true"`

issues.title: How to use thinking in architect mode? (reasoning_effort is unsupported)
issues.body:
### Issue

when running aider with this config:

`--reasoning-effort high` 

`+`

`.aider.conf.yml`

```txt
model: groq/deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b
architect: true

```

`litellm.BadRequestError: GroqException - {"error":{"message":"property 'reasoning_effort' is unsupported, did you mean 'reasoning_format'?","type":"invalid_request_error"}}`

the docs say, that the reasoning parameters only get used for models which do support reasoning. i am confused.

Aider: v0.77.1

@paul-gauthier Using two models presents a challenge.  One model does support that parameter; the other does not.  The parameter should apply only to models that support that parameter.  In this case, that's Claude, not R1.

The documentation is unclear. It states the parameter is for reasoning mode

https://aider.chat/docs/config/reasoning.html

i only see:

> You can use the --reasoning-effort switch to control the reasoning effort of models which support this setting. 

and the important part is:

my problem shows, that this is not true. or am I missing something here ? sorry.

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
It looks like you are using `--reasoning-effort` with R1. It does not support that. The latest build of aider will warn you about this and ignore that switch.

The change is available in the main branch. You can get it by installing the latest version from github:

```
aider --install-main-branch

#

issues.title: Tree-sitter tsx parser hangs sometimes, causing aider to hang
issues.body:
User reports aider hangs when using a repo full of `.tsx` files. Using `--no-git` removes the hang. Issue appears to be in the repo map code.

https://discord.com/channels/1131200896827654144/1192136795077496852

Many reported issues with the tree-sitter tsx parser hanging...

https://github.com/tree-sitter/tree-sitter-typescript/issues/265

Best solution is probably to isolate the parsing so that if it hangs on a single file that doesn't block all the other files in the repo from parsing or hang aider.

issues.title: [regression in 0.74.2+] "metadata: dict" gets transformed into "meta dict"
issues.body:
### Issue

I basically cannot use Aider because of the following issue:

I have a Python source file like this:

```
def make_recipe_gemini(metadata: dict, transcription: str) -> None:
```

Aider basically cannot keep this `metadata: dict` part. It gets transformed into `meta dict`, which of course breaks all code, which it recognised with the internal flake8 pass.

It's not a bug in Claude, it's Aider who is already giving the buggy inputs!


For example, this is still before LLM response, when I ask: 
```
in process.py where is this meta dict coming from??? make it metadata: dict
```

```
-------
ASSISTANT I see there's a typo in the function signature in process.py where it says `meta dict` instead of `meta dict`. I'll need to edit that file to fix it.
ASSISTANT 
ASSISTANT Please add process.py to the chat so I can make the correction.
-------
```

I've managed to create a minimum reproducible .llm.history, uploaded here as txt.

[llm.history.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19034589/llm.history.txt)

### Version and model info

Aider 0.75.1
model: openrouter/anthropic/claude-3.7-sonnet (same with 3.5)
issues.author: hyperknot

- 0.74.2 **broken**

comments.body:
That setting controls how to summarize "older" parts of the conversation, things which were said before the most recent LLM edit of files was completed. It has no effect on the "current" portion of the conversation, the part since the last LLM edit.

What are you trying to do?

comments.author: tom-doerr

comments.author: paul-gauthier

It sounds like you want to load up a large amount of context, squash/summarize it and then send it to the LLM? Do you imagine it summarizing code and non-code content?

This is all different than the functionality which aider has now, which is to summarize older history to prevent the conversation h

issues.title: Yanked Dependencies Prevent Installing v0.75.2+
issues.body:
### Issue

tldr: `aiohttp 3.11.14` and `fsspec 2025.3.1` are both yanked, using later versions *appears* to work?

I first followed the "get started quickly" with `pipx install aider-install` and later the "install with uv" method since that appears to be used under-the-hood. Without overrides, aiohttp appears to uv force to use 0.75.1 as the latest aider-chat version.

With aiohttp over-ridden, fsspec allows 0.79.2 as the latest.

I was able to install 0.80.0 by over-riding them both with the newest non-yanked versions. It installs and runs, but it's not my place to say it works as intended.
```
echo -e "aiohttp==3.11.12\nfsspec==2025.3.2" > ./requirements.txt && uv tool install --force --python python3.12 --overrides ./requirements.txt aider-chat@0.80.0 && rm ./requirements.txt 
```



### Version and model info

N/A
issues.author: Kajmany

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body: Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue. Sorry, what problem are you experiencing? Aider is building fine in CI for Windows and Linux.

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body: Ah, I see the issue. v0.80.1 will be out shortly using the non-yanked versions.

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body: It's out now, thanks for the heads up.

comments.author: Kajmany
comments.body:
Thank you for your quick work! I assume it would be ideal to fail CI in these cases(?)

Edit: Oops, I thought there was no warning in the runner as PEP 592 **SHOULDs**, but there is.

issues.title: Typescript file crashes repo-map
issues.body:
### Issue

When I try to include this file (that aider created!) the repo-mapper hangs in an ugly way.

Processing /home/tdobson/Videos/dev/cavingcrew-hybrid-headless-react/.gitignore
Updating repo map Processing /home/tdobson/Videos/dev/cavingcrew-hybrid-headless-react/README.md
Processing /home/tdobson/Videos/dev/cavingcrew-hybrid-headless-react/hybrid-headless-front-end/.biomeignore
<snip>
Processing /home/tdobson/Videos/dev/cavingcrew-hybrid-headless-react/hybrid-headless-front-end/components/trips/NeoClanVolunteeringWidget.tsx

This file crashes the Repo-map:
https://pastebin.com/raw/sR5qaZej (please feel free to try it - I confirmed that the formatting copy/pasted from this pastebin reproduces it here).

What you experience is a hang, where you can't ctrl-c or ctrl-d out of it, and you have to run killall aider.
The CPU also churns.

Here's the verbose startup log in full

https://pastebin.com/raw/yAANST4Z

I'm not a low level programmer, but I tried
strace aider --model sonnet --auto-lint --no-attribute-committer --no-attribute-author --cache-prompts   --lint-cmd "../magicLinter.sh" --test-cmd="npm run test" --verbose --show-repo-map 

and the interesting bit might be:
close(5)                                = 0
brk(0x3e0ed000)                         = 0x3e0ed000
brk(0x3e10e000)                         = 0x3e10e000
brk(0x3e12f000)                         = 0x3e12f000
brk(0x3e150000)                         = 0x3e150000

You can see the whole strace output here:
https://paste.debian.net/plainh/582c4fd5

and another more detailed strace
https://paste.debian.net/plain/1361883 
showing the code is getting stuck in a futex (fast userspace mutex) waiting loop

I'm going to try removing the file, feeding it to the model as input and asking it to recreate it... 

--

Oh, I've also tried remove .aider.tags.cache.v3 and letting aider recreate it. That didn't help.

Thanks for the wonderful tool you've built

### Version and model info

weak_model_name: "anthropic/claude-3-5-haiku-20241022"
RepoMap initialized with map_mul_no_files: 2

issues.title: Support for Signed Commits
issues.body:

I have `git config commit.gpgSign` set to `true`. 

Aider fails to create commits because they cannot be signed:

```
Unable to commit: Cmd('git') failed due to: exit code(128)

gpg: skipped "Anton Engelhardt (aider) <xxx@icloud.com>": No secret key
[GNUPG:] INV_SGNR 9 Anton Engelhardt (aider) <xxx@icloud.com>
[GNUPG:] FAILURE sign 17
gpg: signing failed: No secret key

fatal: failed to write commit object'
```

Is there any way to fix this apart from turning the git flag off or turning auto-commits off?

v0.56.0

issues.title: Q: [Docs] Improve Python Scripting API Documentation with Practical Examples
issues.body:
### Issue

**Labels:** `documentation`, `enhancement`, `python-api`

**Summary:**

The current documentation for the Python scripting API is lacking in practical, codebase-derived examples. This issue proposes updating the documentation with multiple code snippets based on common use cases seen within the aider project itself. This will offer users clearer guidance on how to use the API effectively, while also providing examples that should be more stable over time.

**Motivation:**

*   The existing documentation is abstract, lacking real-world examples that can help users quickly understand how to apply the Python API.
*   Users need to see a variety of usage patterns, demonstrating how to chain requests, pass in various parameters and work with the results.
*   Users need a sense for how best to handle errors, or problems they may encounter when using the API.
*   Using examples from the existing codebase makes the examples more practical, more durable and less error prone.

**Proposed Changes:**

*   **Provide enhanced documentation using concrete examples:** Showcase different use cases with clear, practical examples. Use code from the aider repo itself, which is well tested.
*   **Explain core classes:**  Clarify the purposes of and interactions between `aider.coders.Coder`, `aider.models.Model`, and `aider.io.InputOutput` with real-world examples.
*   **Illustrate method usage:** Demonstrate how to effectively use `Coder.create()` and `Coder.run()` to send messages and apply changes.
*   **Add specific examples:** Provide a number of new examples that cover these topics:
    *   Basic scripting, showing how to create the `Coder` and call `run()`.
    *   Chaining together multiple commands.
    *   Customizing a Coder by selecting a specific model, edit format and other parameters.
    *   Working with temporary directories to manage temporary files while working with the API.
    *   Setting the --yes parameter via the IO class.
    *   Provide examples that return the output of `coder.run()` and error handling.
*   **Clearly state limitations:** Warn users about the unofficial nature of the API, so they understand that changes may occur over time, which may require updates to their scripts.

**Example Code Snippets (from the proposed documentation):**

**Basic Scripting Example:**
```python
from aider.coders import Coder
from aider.models import Model
from aider.io import InputOutput

# This is a list of files to add to the chat
fnames = ["greeting.py"]

model = Model("gpt-4-turbo")

# Create an io object (required) and optionally enable confirmations with yes=True
io = InputOutput(yes=True)

# Create a coder object
coder = Coder.create(main_model=model, io=io, fnames=fnames)

# This will execute one instruction on those files and then return the last LLM message
result = coder.run("make a script that prints hello world")
print(result)
```

**Chain Multiple Instructions**
```python
from aider.coders import Coder
from aider.models import Model
from aider.io import InputOutput

# This is a list of files to add to the chat
fnames = ["greeting.py"]

model = Model("gpt-4-turbo")
# Create an io object
io = InputOutput(yes=True)

# Create a coder object
coder = Coder.create(main_model=model, io=io, fnames=fnames)

# This will execute one instruction on those files
result1 = coder.run("make a script that prints hello world")
print("Result 1:", result1)

# Send another instruction
result2 = coder.run("make it say goodbye")
print("Result 2:", result2)

# You can run in-chat "/" commands too
result3 = coder.run("/tokens")
print("Result 3:", result3)
```

**Using `Coder.create` with Custom Settings**
```python
from aider.coders import Coder
from aider.models import Model
from aider.io import InputOutput
from aider.coders.base_coder import UnknownEditFormat

try:
    # Create an io object and use it for both Coder instances
    io = InputOutput(
        pretty=True,
        yes=True,
    )

    # Use gpt-3.5-turbo with a specific diff edit format for the main Coder
    model1 = Model("gpt-3.5-turbo")
    coder1 = Coder.create(main_model=model1, edit_format="udiff", io=io, fnames=["code.py"])
    result1 = coder1.run("Write a fibonacci method.")
    print("Coder 1 Result:", result1)

    # Use a different model and edit format for a second coder.
    model2 = Model("gpt-4")
    coder2 = Coder.create(main_model=model2, edit_format="whole", io=io)
    result2 = coder2.run("make a class to hold the result")
    print("Coder 2 Result:", result2)

except UnknownEditFormat as e:
    print(f"Failed to create Coder with bad edit format: {e}")
```

**Working with Temporary Files**
```python
import tempfile
from pathlib import Path

from aider.coders import Coder
from aider.models import Model
from aider.io import InputOutput

with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as temp_dir:
    # create a new file in a temporary dir
    test_file = Path(temp_dir) / "test_file.py"
    with open(test_file, 'w') as f:
        f.write("initial content")

    model = Model("gpt-4-turbo")
    # create an io object
    io = InputOutput(yes=True)

    # Create a coder object
    coder = Coder.create(main_model=model, io=io, fnames=[str(test_file)])
    # Run aider to edit the temporary file
    coder.run("Make it say hello")

    print(f"Content of {test_file}: {test_file.read_text()}")
```

**Additional Notes:**

*   The core of this example uses the "text" property to get the contents of the messages that come back from the LLM.
*   The IO object is a required argument. Aider also requires that it is set up with the desired options, like `yes`.
*   This example showcases some of the options supported in `Coder.create()`.

**Impact:**

This improvement would enable developers to more easily integrate Aider into their workflows and create powerful automation scripts.

**Next Steps:**

*   Implement changes to `aider/website/docs/scripting.md`.
*   Review new examples for correctness and clarity.
*   Test all examples against the latest version of aider.

Let me know if you'd like any adjustments or if there's anything else I can do to help.

### Version and model info

_No response_

issues.title: Don't display gitignore message when .aider* is in the global gitignore
issues.body:
### Issue

When starting aider in a git repo that has no .gitignore, but the gitconfig has a global exclude file that already excludes aider files, it still asks to modify the current repo with .aider* gitignores.

In the gitconfig an excludes file can be specified as so:
```
core.excludesfile=~/.gitignore_global
```

If aider gitignores are in that file, it could skip prompting to modify the current project because effectively the person is already ignoring them.

### Version and model info

aider 0.72.3
issues.author: leighmcculloch

comments.author: karlb
comments.body: It might be out of scope for aider, but it would also be nice if aider suggested a single global ignore rather than adding the ignore to every repo. See also https://sebastiandedeyne.com/setting-up-a-global-gitignore-file/. That would be a great multiplier for showing people the (IMO) right way.

comments.author: leighmcculloch
comments.body: +1 The main reason I put aider's ignores into the global ignore instead of the repo ignore is because it's more to do with my own personal development environment and less to do with the project itself.

comments.author: bkudria
comments.body: I can second this, I'm trying aider at work on a shared repository that I shouldn't add arbitrary ignore rules to. Currently, aider shows me this prompt every time I start it.

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

What do you have in your global ignore file? Aider checks for `.aider*` not `.aider.*` which is a common misunderstanding.

Also you can do `--no-gitignore` to skip this check.

issues.title: `/drop` shouldn't drop read-only files unless explicitly requested
issues.body:
When I'm done working on a task with a subset of files and want to start working on the next task, I run `/drop` to start (semi-)fresh. However, this also drops my read-only `CONVENTIONS.md` file.

`/drop` should only drop read-only files when specifically requested. In this case, `/drop` should leave `CONVENTIONS.md` loaded, and only `/drop CONVENTIONS.md` would drop that file.
issues.author: harleypig

comments.author: jkendall327
comments.body: I also run against this behaviour a lot. I go through a cycle of running `/drop` and `/clear` frequently and it's annoying needing to always re-add the conventions file.

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

The main branch has a change where `/drop` without args will not drop files which were added read-only on launch. So if you use `--read` or the yaml/env versions, they won't be dropped unless you explicitly name them in the `/drop` command.

See #3289.

comments.author: jkendall327
comments.body: I've just tried this out briefly and it works exactly as I would like. Thank you very much for the change.

comments.author: github-actions[bot]
comments.body:

comments.author: harleypig
comments.body: I'm sorry. I forgot to close this. It works as expected. Thank you.

issues.title: Please add the ability to auto-accept architect suggestions
issues.body:
### Issue

Summary:
  * Please add `--architect-auto-accept`

Hi there, I developed a front end to aid.chat called `advanced-aicode` (you can install it with `pip install advanced-aicode` and then use `aicode`, which makes aider easier to use and uses better defaults. I've been developing it off an on since aider first became popular.

I recently turned made architect mode the default when it launches aider.

The architect mode is very powerful! However it's adding a little bit of UX friction in that it requires that I say yes to the proposed edits. I'd like to propose the option to pass a command line arg to aider chat so that it can always assume yes for applying the edits for architect mode.

This allows the workflow where we are using VSCode's git visual diff to look at the file diff. This is much easier to use than looking at the raw diff edits.

Something like `--architect-auto-accept`

*Misc*

I want to mention that one of the best features of `advanced-aicode` is that it has special logic for creating an isolated environment using uv for the private aider.chat install. This avoids dependency issues that everyone in this space is facing right now. I think if you backported this feature into aider it would really make it a better product to install. I used pipx before but that doesn't want to remove the aider.chat install and made upgrading aider.chat a work of brain surgery. This upgrade system I have because of UV is nearly painless, although there are corner cases if `aicode` is running in other processes, but for those corner cases and do rollback and restore the install when a locked file exception is thrown during upgrade.

Anyway, thanks for such a great open source project. 

### Version and model info

Aider 0.62.1

`aider`suggests this fix 

```

> Repo-map can't include  .../src/lib/zzzzzz
To handle the case where the file is a symbolic link to a file in a git submodule, we can use the os.path.realpath() function. This function follows the symbolic link and returns the actual file path.

Here's how we can modify the code:

 for fname in fnames:
     real_path = os.path.realpath(fname)
     if not Path(real_path).is_file():
         self.io.tool_error(f"Repo-map can't include {fname}")
         continue

This code will follow the symbolic link and check if the actual file exists. If the file doesn't exist, it will print an error message and continue with the next file.
```

issues.title: LLM output slow compared to Ollama
issues.body:
### Issue

I'm hosting LLMs on a remote Ollama server with nvidia gpus. If I point ollama to the server and start a chat session with `ollama run`, I get a perfectly reasonable streaming response from the server (~50 tokens/s). If I point Aider to the same server, there is often a ~10s delay before receiving anything back, and the streaming rate is perceivably lower. I couldn't figure out how to report timing metrics from Aider or I would post a quantitative comparison.

In addition to a delay before response, I've noticed sometimes that deepseek-r1 will slow to a crawl when responding with code edits.

In contrast, if I point to gpt-4o the response is BLAZINGLY fast. 

Any suggestions on how I can profile and troubleshoot this speed issue?

### Version and model info

Aider v0.74.2
Model: mistral, deepseek-r1:32b
Git repo: empty
issues.author: plandrem

comments.author: plandrem
comments.body: It seems like this may be tied to the model loading time in Ollama. I've noticed that my first message after ollama run can have a 7 second delay. Subsequent messages in ollama run have ms delay, but aider seems to keep the 7s loading time...

comments.author: plandrem
comments.body: bump

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

How much data do you send the model when you use it directly and see "fast" replies? When you use aider, you're sending it make k-tokens of context, which will slow replies.

comments.author: plandrem
comments.body: I was testing with ~2.5k tokens, trying to match the report that Aider provides after completing an edit. Is there a way to get timings from aider? If yes, I can do some profiling experiments

issues.title: Whitespace errors in the git commits - autoformat before commit
issues.body:
### Issue

Looking at the git log of a bunch of aider commits, I see a lot of red due to whitespace errors (e.g. lines with just a bunch of spaces in them). I'm guessing this is an issue for most programming languages (I'm using Rust and C++).

It would be nice if aider either could clean this up itself before committing, or support common code formatting tools (clang-format, rustfmt, ...) to automatically do this before committing.

### Version and model info

Aider v0.70.0
Main model: claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022 with diff edit format, infinite output
Weak model: claude-3-5-haiku-20241022
Git repo: .git with 46 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens, auto refresh
issues.author: gcp

comments.author: gcp
comments.body:
>support common code formatting tools (clang-format, rustfmt, ...) to automatically do this before committing.

To be clear, I'm aware this could potentially be done with hooks, but that's not appropriate for all codebases. Still, the code that aider writes could be cleaned up.

comments.author: GCBallesteros
comments.body: Couldn't we have an `auto-format` and `format-cmd` option in the same way we have `auto-lint` and `lint-cmd`. I too find myself going over all the modified files running a formatter and then having to do a rebase.

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

You can use the lint command for this type of formatting. The lint command is intended for any sort of command that should be run on each file that has been edited.

comments.author: GCBallesteros

issues.title: Unexpected High Costs for Keep-Alive Requests with Sonnet Model
issues.body:
### Issue

Hi, there might be a bug in prompt caching when using Sonnet models via OpenRouter. It seems to not be asking for caching most of the prompts.

I tried checking if  it was an OpenRouter issue, but querying Sonnet-OR via litellm charges cache prices correctly.

If we were caching the full inputs, each keep-alive should cost approximately: 14198/1e6 * 0.3 + 2/1e6 * 15 = 0,0042894

But it's costing 0,0378

I'm trying to debug the litellm requests on my local aider to see if I can find a bug, but you guys know the codebase much better, so this is why I opened an issue.

Here's an image of the costs of the keep-alive by Aider:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5a72b7bd-e599-47b0-a3d6-de55bc60ed47)

Here's one of the transactions:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/36a537a3-119d-4e62-afa5-d4dd22eb8bbe)

Here's my .aider.conf
```
model: openrouter/anthropic/claude-3.7-sonnet
weak-model: openrouter/google/gemini-2.0-flash-lite-preview-02-05:free
timeout: 60
cache-prompts: true
stream: false
cache-keepalive-pings: 6
```

Thanks! Love aider!

### Version and model info

Aider v0.77.0
Main model: openrouter/anthropic/claude-3.7-sonnet with diff edit format, prompt cache, infinite output
Weak model: openrouter/google/gemini-2.0-flash-lite-preview-02-05:free
Git repo: .git with 64 files
Repo-map: using 4096 tokens, files refresh

It seems caching the assistant message that comes after it doesn't cache the user message, so a fix might be adding cache_con

issues.title: feature request: allow for external or internal plugins for commands
issues.body:
blue-sky idea, but I can see use-cases where plugins to aider is useful:

- attach a PR/MR to an issue in github/gitlab
- pull/select PR/MR that should be reviewed (by querying github/gitlab APIs)
- import gitlab/github issue description into context before starting to implement a feature.
- import hackmd document into context (could be a design document)

aider could provide a file-based API  (file x contains context, y contains list of edited files, z contains bar), and then exec aider-foo for the /foo command, similar to how `git` handles external commands.
issues.author: alexanderkjeldaas

``

issues.title: UV installed Aider not able to run globally installed git
issues.body:
### Issue

Hi, 
Following documentation, I installed aider chat using:
`uv tool install --force --python python3.12 aider-chat@latest`

Running aider, it can't find git and returns this error:
```
Unable to diff: Cmd('git') not found due to: FileNotFoundError('[Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'git'')
  cmdline: git diff --cached -- factorial.py
```

Similar issue applies to playwright, aider also doesn't seem to have knowledge of globally installed playwright and asks to install it. If installation is accepted, the installation passes but fails on the chromium install.

It seems that aider doesn't have knowledge of anything available on the shell or globally.

Both git and playwright are in the path and available from any shell.


### Version and model info

Aider: v0.72.2
OS: linux 6.12.10.arch1-1
Git: 2.48.1-1

issues.title: Suggestion: See what the reasoning models are thinking before they give their output.
issues.body: ### Issue Since I was facing a lot of wait time using reasoning models like [DeepSeek R1](https://openrouter.ai/deepseek/deepseek-r1) and [Perplexity: Sonar Reasoning](https://openrouter.ai/perplexity/sonar-reasoning) in Aider, i.e an average wait time in minutes even for simple prompts like: > Ignore any other prompt before this. Tell me how many "r"s are in the word "Strawberry" I tried testing them out in Openrouter's chatroom. I noticed that the models/APIs were not lagging, but that they took a lot of time to think before they responded. And I could see what they were thinking as they did. It would help my user experience A LOT, if I could see this thought process when using Aider. Do I have to wait because it's thinking, is it thinking in the right direction? (If it's not, I can cancel the request and direct it better) Or is it the API just stuck? Since the OpenRouter chatroom can get the reasoning tokens, I assume that we can too? ### Version and model info aider 0.72.3 model: openrouter/deepseek/deepseek-r1

issues.title: Race Condition: File addition vs. Instruction execution timing
issues.body:
### Issue

Hi, 
It appears that there is a race condition between adding the files to the context and executing the instructions provided by the message file.

What I observe is that sometimes (this happens more frequently with smaller files than with larger ones), Aider responds with:
"To proceed with the task, I need to see the full contents of the file..."

However, the file is already added, as shown in the log below:

```
Aider v0.74.2
Model: azure/gpt-4o with ask edit format
Git repo: .git with 15 files
Repo-map: using 4096 tokens, auto refresh
Added test-data-set/strncat.cpp to the chat (read-only).

To proceed with the task, I need to see the full contents of the file `test-data-set/strncat.cpp` to analyze the specific line and surrounding code. Please add the full contents of `test-data-set/strncat.cpp` to the chat.
Tokens: 1.7k sent, 55 received. Cost: $0.0092 message, $0.0092 session.
```

Is it possible that both actions - adding the file and executing the instructions - are being executed asynchronously in parallel? If so, could this be causing a situation where the file addition is not yet complete while the execution of the instruction file has already started?

Here are the command-line parameters used for the call:

```
aider --chat-mode ask --model azure/gpt-4o -f /home/tgeghamyan/src/hotspotter/aider-instructions.txt --read 
./test-data-set/strncat.cpp --yes-always --no-pretty 
```

Thanks,
TG

### Version and model info

Aider v0.74.2
Model: azure/gpt-4o with ask edit format
Git repo: .git with 15 files
Repo-map: using 4096 tokens, auto refresh
issues.author: geghamyan

issues.title: Cannot add image as read-only to the chat
issues.body:
### Issue

When I try to add a jpg to the chat as read-only. I receive a: 'No matches found for: y.jpg' response.
However when I try to add the same image as Editable, then the image will be added as Editable.

Expected:

- Image should be added as read-only, instead of returning a 'No matches found for: y.jpg' response.

```
/read-only x.pdf                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
```
> Added /app/x.pdf to read-only files.
> 
> Readonly: x.pdf    

```
/read-only y.jpg                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
```

> No matches found for: y.jpg
> 
> Readonly: x.pdf     

```
/add y.jpg                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
```

> Added y.jpg to the chat
> 
> Readonly: x.pdf
> Editable: y.jpg

Aidler: paulgauthier/aider-full:latest docker image: sha256:d949ec3f0cc5afba3b1110f01a0f357c10f9134970127e644f5b49c63264d9d8

I have a `secrets` directory that is owned by `root`. I also have an `.env` file owned by root.

```
$ l -d  deployarr/{.env,secrets}
-rw-------+ 1 root root  643 Feb 19 00:41 deployarr/.env

issues.title: How can I get aider to automatically execute the commands so I don't have to type Yes all the time?
issues.body:
How can I get aider to automatically execute the commands so I don't have to type Yes all the time?

Got it to run with a custom LLM today, good feeling : )
issues.author: bitcoinmeetups

comments.author: Emasoft
comments.body:
Just use `--yes-always` when launching aider, as indicated in the aider options docs:
https://aider.chat/docs/config/options.html#--yes-always

Unfortunately it is all or nothing. I would like aider to implement a more fine grained approach to this.

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

Aider never executes shell commands without explicit human approval. They could do serious damage to your system if the LLM suggests a wrong and dangerous command.

comments.author: marvijo-code
comments.body: I agree with @Emasoft, a whitelist would make Aider much more agentic.

issues.title: Add Tree-sitter Markdown Parser Support for Repository Map
issues.body:
### Issue

I would like to request the addition of Tree-sitter support for Markdown to the aider repository map feature. The [tree-sitter-markdown](https://github.com/tree-sitter-grammars/tree-sitter-markdown) grammar provides parsing capabilities for Markdown files, which would be beneficial for projects using Markdown documentation.

Proposal:

Integration with Repository Map: Include the Tree-sitter Markdown parser to generate repository maps for Markdown files. This will allow aider to analyze and include Markdown file structure in the repository map, providing better context for documentation alongside code.

Required Changes:

Implement the tags.scm query file for Markdown as needed.
Integrate the Markdown parser into the existing repository mapping infrastructure, ensuring compatibility with other supported languages.
Benefits:

Enhanced understanding of Markdown documentation for AI-assisted programming and repository navigation.
Improved cross-referencing between code and documentation, facilitating better context for users and AI.
Thank you for considering this feature request.

### Version and model info

_No response_
issues.author: lightningRalf

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

Markdown is currently disabled for the repo map, because the tree-sitter markdown parser sometimes crashes and takes down the entire aider process.

issues.title: Auto drop images!!!
issues.body:
### Issue

I would like to streamline aider workflow slightly

currently the way is 
- screenshot (mac cmd+shift+opt+4),
- run `/paste`, 
- after the next message we type `/drop clipboard` 
- tab complete it, hit enter, to drop the image

the big friction point is having to manually remove the image being active in the chat, because the common case is to discard it. I would like to have a hotkey i can hit to automate `/drop` for something matching a pattern!

Even better! By default drop any images. If we want it back we can easily copy the file path that was shown in the earlier prompt in the terminal... or since with official flow it's still potentially in the clipboard one could just re-run `/paste`!

So then for the streamlined workflow what I would love to have is: 

- auto drop images after one prompt to aider with the image
- a hotkey we can type to run `/paste` to slurp up image immediately without typing `/paste`. no biggie since user can /drop it manually if it was accidental. Bonus points if we can hit the key and make it do this to add the image from clipboard while we are already in the middle of prompt editing.
issues.author: unphased

comments.author: 5ocworkshop
comments.body: I've had a similar thought, I like your idea.  Maybe instead of auto-drop we could confirm to drop when the next prompt is submitted and an image that was already submitted is still included in the chat?  Basically the same effect but if you did intend to leave it, you can.

comments.author: unphased
comments.body: I think that's good. It does make me wonder, if images included in past prompts carry forward in the chat history or not. I've simply never had a need to re-submit the same image but maybe depending on the model it could be something that is needed sometimes!

comments.author: 5ocworkshop
comments.body: My understanding is that all files loaded in the current chat will be re-submitted with each query, including the images.

comments.author: unphased
comments.body: what i was asking about was whether images could be included as part of "chat history" even if it is removed from the list of context files. It is doubtful since each MLLM has its own specific tokenization schemes for images and i assume chat history is assembled into one big string/file.

That is an interesting question, I don't have any visibility in to that one but am now interested in learning the answer :)

I also need to turn on --verbose and see if I can get a sense of how the files you include are ordered when submitted.

watch.py's filter_func then filters out any file changes in common/ since the "wildcard everything" config matches.

issues.body:
### Issue

i use claude and deepseek and i find that i have to keep restarting aider (switching from deepseek to claude) a lot because deepseek will just not work.
it's not slow, it just will stop responding to my prompts and waiting for 10+ minutes returns nothing. i'm using the leaderboard params. i've also tried with only deepseek.

some feedback would be good.

i haven't had this issue with claude.

i think that deepseek may be timing out and there is no message being reported in this case, or maybe something weirder is happening like it opens a connection that doesn't get sent further data. i'm just speculating, i haven't packet sniffed. i haven't tried [--verbose](https://aider.chat/docs/config/options.html#--verbose), as i just found that option. i'll use it next session to see if i get any better info when i hit this problem.

aider 0.72.3
model deepseek-reasoner
arch linux
issues.author: boxxxie

issues.title: Feature Request: Option to limit retries when search/replace blocks fail
issues.body:
Currently, when Aider receives malformed search and replace blocks from the LLM, it automatically attempts to recover by requesting corrected blocks from the LLM. While this is very helpful in most cases, it can also lead to:

1. Multiple failed iteration cycles
2. Unnecessary API token consumption and increased costs
3. Frustration when the error is not recoverable (e.g., when the LLM is working with outdated code)

**Proposed Solution:**
Add configuration options to control retry behavior:
- A maximum number of retries before giving up
- An option to prompt the user before attempting retries
- (Optional) A way to completely disable automatic retries

**Benefits:**
- Reduced API costs from failed recovery attempts
- Better user experience when manual intervention is preferred
- More control over the editing process
- Faster workflow when users want to manually edit code after a failed attempt

---

Aider version: 0.63.1
Python version: 3.12.7
Platform: macOS-15.1-arm64-arm-64bit
Python implementation: CPython
Virtual environment: Yes
OS: Darwin 24.1.0 (64bit)
Git version: git version 2.39.5 (Apple Git-154)

Aider v0.63.1
Main model: claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022 with diff edit format, prompt cache, infinite output
Weak model: claude-3-5-haiku-20241022
Git repo: .git with 1,118 files
Warning: For large repos, consider using --subtree-only and .aiderignore
See: https://aider.chat/docs/faq.html#can-i-use-aider-in-a-large-mono-repo
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens, files refresh

issues.title: features to support Jupyter notebooks better
issues.body:
I tried asking aider to add a cell to a Jupyter notebook. It *worked*, but showing the diff is kind of low-level, because it's a JSON diff. (I suppose this is a side-effect of Jupyter notebooks not being especially friendly for editing in plain text.)

The notebook looks okay, but it doesn't include the prompt that I gave to GPT4, or GPT4's non-code responses. Also, aider auto-committed the change, which is bad because I didn't execute the notebook cell yet. (This generates the image.)

Maybe Jupyter notebook integration should be a different project altogether, but here are some suggestions:

 * Convert a Python notebook to a different format that's more friendly to send to GPT4? This could reduce the amount of time spent generating boilerplate.
 
* When GPT4 adds one code cell to a notebook, add the prompt as a markdown cell before the code cell that GPT4 added.

* Instead of auto-committing, maybe aider should pop up the file in your text editor and let you edit it? (In this case, VS Code.)

issues.title: "Run Shell Commands" Ideation
issues.body:
Just some thoughts about how to make shell commands more friendly. There are likely a few things people might want to do.
* Not run shell commands
* Edit the shell command before running it
* Prompt or Ask for more details about the command
* `/clear` before running shell command

v0.54.12
```
python my.py --row 2 --field Labels
Run shell command? (Y)es/(N)o [Yes]: n
You can use /undo to undo and discard each aider commit.
---
my.py
> 
```

Suggestion
```
You can use /undo to undo and discard each aider commit.
---
my.py
> /run python my.py --row 2 --field Labels
```

Some feature that might better handle these use cases.
* Down arrow can move to empty prompt
* Left arrow can allow cursor movement to the characters the user wishes to add or change
* Home can allow cursor to more to start allowing user to change /run to /ask or something different
* Add shell command to history. This would allow user to run `/clear` and then up arrow to the "/run" command.

I'm not saying this is the ultimate UX, just ideating :).

    return Style.from_dict(style_dict)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "style.py", line 266, in from_dict
    return cls(list(style_dict.items()))
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "style.py", line 239, in __init__
    attrs = _parse_style_str(style_str)

    attrs = attrs._replace(color=parse_color(part))

    raise ValueError(f"Wrong color format {text!r}")

```

This seems like an error aider could recover from, automatically inserting an `#` if the color is otherwise valid.

Also - the default yaml config should probably include quotes around the default colors, since `#` is a YAML quote character :D

issues.title: Adding default git config user.name, user.email is too aggressive
issues.body:
### Issue

In our environment we explicitly forbid users from setting user.name, user.email in their git config and instead allow git to pick it up from the environment. When running Aider it sets them in the local repository if they're not set which then breaks our check in verification hooks. Can we perhaps issue a warning instead?

aider 0.50.1 installed via pipx
model not relevant since this is an aider startup issue.

issues.title: support for gitconfig include directives
issues.body:
### Issue

I have my git user.name set by using git config includes ([docs](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-config#_includes)):
```
$ git config --get user.name
Felix Hummel
```

Steps:
```
git init .
aider
```

Expected: Aider does nothing concerning `user.name` or `user.email`.

Actual: Aider outputs the following warning and writes `.git/config`
```
Update git name with: git config user.name "Your Name"
Update git email with: git config user.email "you@example.com"
```

It would be nice if aider would use git's parsing of its configuration `git user.name` and `git user.email`.

### Version and model info

aider 0.69.1

issues.title: lint-cmd configuation needs more examples
issues.body:
### Issue

Hi, thank you for creating such an amazing tool and making it open source. 🙏

I am trying to configure a custom linter for a fairly niche language. Here is what I am trying:

```
auto-lint: true
lint-cmd:
 - clojurescript: clj-kondo --lint
 - clojure: clj-kondo --lint
 - cljs: clj-kondo --lint
```

Which results in the following error:

```
/bin/sh: line 1: {cljs:: command not found

# Fix any errors below, if possible.

## Running: {'cljs': 'clj-kondo --lint'} style.css

/bin/sh: line 1: {cljs:: command not found

## See relevant line below marked with █.

style.css:
```

It seems like it's trying to run the entire last YAML block converted to JSON as the command. How can I specify that I want files with extension `*.cljs` to be run with a particular command, and no other files run with that command?

Thank you very much.

### Version and model info

aider 0.73.0

issues.title: Support multiple instances of aider, for parallel workflow
issues.body:
I'd like to be able to have multiple instances of aider running at a time so I can work on multiple tasks.

GPT-4 can be slow and  I spend a lot of time waiting.  I could use that time working on related tasks.

My current workaround is a separate branch in a git worktree, but it's very clunky.  I have to merge often.

Currently, problems with running two aider processes are: log files get overwritten, file contents might be stale, and work could get mixed when creating the diff.   Possible solutions:

* Per-process logs.  Have an optional env var to specify a namespace as a file prefix.
* Git lock file.  While creating the diff, create a lock file.  Other aider processes will wait if lock file exists.
* Check added files after every prompt entry.   Reload any files that were changed (this might already be the case).
issues.author: mikeslattery

comments.author: mikeslattery

As a workaround, I wrote a sync utility, `git-syncr`.  You can fork off multiple directories from a feature branch.

```sh
git syncr add ../worktree2
cd ../worktree2
aider
```

And within aider you run `/git sync` or `/run git-syncr sync` to synchronize the directories.

issues.title: Feature Request : make aider 'time aware'
issues.body:
### Issue

As well as coding, I've found a great use case for aider in being my bullet journal assistant.   I can have a bujo.md file and aider creates diary notes, shows me my reminders, summaries monthly plans..  it's amazing and changing completely how I interact with a diary.

However sometime aider get confused as to what day it is, or doesn't know 'today'.    This is obviously a model issue, not specifically aider, so it would be great if aider just knew the date through either a date command, or some internal magic.

I keep using 

`> /run date`

but sometimes forget.

this would also be great for putting timestamps/date in code changes and function definitions.

### Version and model info

_No response_
issues.author: agileandy

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

Aider includes the date when using the normal "diff" edit format.

```
$ aider --show-prompt | grep date
- Current date: 2025-02-05
```

comments.author: agileandy
comments.body:
Thanks for the prompt reply Paul. 

I agree this would work and is similar to the > run date command I'm currently using.   However it does rely on me rerunning the command regularly, especially across a multi day session.   This is why I was wondering if this was something aider could just be aware

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body: Every time you send a message it sends the updated current date.

comments.author: agileandy
comments.body: Hi Paul, Maybe I'm misunderstanding this. Launching a new session and asking Aider for the date I get 2 July 2024. However running the date through terminal is shows todays date. Aider then acknowledge the mistake and returns the correct date.

comments.author: agileandy
comments.body:
I figured out a way to get this to do what I need.  

I've changed my alias to include the **--load** option and given it a **time.aider** file.

**time.aider** then contains

```

/run date "+Today is %A %e %B %Y"

```

Now every time I open my bujo alias aider responds with todays date.

issues.title: Suggestion: Multi Agent (Supervisor/Reviewer agent)
issues.body:
Hello,

Sorry if this is the wrong place to suggest, but I have been using Aider in production for some time now, it's great but it can be even greather if it allows us to add multiple agents or more than 1 layer of answer. Let me explain:

1. I ask Aider to change an existing class for me
2. Aider modifies the code
3. I have to review the code to check if he does not mess up with the current functionality of the code

Well, we will always do the 3rd, but Aider would be even greater if we can add an extra layer of response. Basically, a code reviewer that you can enable or not, how it would work:

1. Same
2. Same
3. Modified code go through the "reviewer agent", the instructions of the reviewer can be custom, I would use something like: "You received a request to do X, please check if your resulting code does as asked, also, please make sure your changes were just the needed to perform the task and nothing outside this scope was modified." - He can emit an opinion like "Reviewer says: The code is OK". (I'm talking about an extra request to GTP or whatever AI)
4. I review the code but more confident now ;)

The "reviewer" is basically just an extra layer of response, it can be anything, and even can have multi layers that allows the result to be more scrutinized and improved. Ex: I can have an extra layer asking it to improve the performance of the generated code.

I've searched for similar tools with multiple agents, but the only tool that I found that modifies well an existing code base is Aider, AI is going to the path of multi-agents, one that verifies what the previous one did, this suggestion follows this same trend and would be really useful.


Thanks for building Aider s2

issues.title: pre-commit hooks are ignored by Aider when used on projects
issues.body:
### Issue

Hi, this is a really fantastic project !!!

Recently, I noticed Aider isn't respecting pre-commit hooks for projects.  I have tried both the .git/hooks/precommit and the python pre-commit package and in all cases failing pre-commit hook tests will not prevent Aider from committing to a repo.  

I'm not sure if this could be due to the default Aider auto-commit mode using `--no-verify` somewhere ( I don't see any places in the repo where this is happening) or if instead this might be a side effect of the  gitpython client library.  I have found a function in the gitpython docs [run_commit_hook](https://gitpython.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference.html?highlight=hook#git.index.fun.run_commit_hook), but my limited understanding is that gitpython doesn't respect hooks and only gives you the run_commit_hook to manually override specific commits you pass through.  I think it would be easy to add a feature to look at the .git/hooks/repo/precommit or .precommit yaml to pass through precommit calls to the gitpython function.  Alternatively,  would it be possible to set the autocommit to use shell command git so the hooks get picked up?

1) Is there a way to make Aider to respect pre-commit hooks with commits or autocommits?
2) Is there a better workflow for forcing Aider to iterate on a prompt until tests are passing?

I have been using Aider for web development tasks that included end-to-end and integration tests for nodejs api service with jest testing and I have noticed that Aider can sometimes break a number of tests without realizing it.  I would like to use pre-commit test hooks to make Aider stop and correct broken tests before moving forward.  In an ideal setting the pre-commit test hook would run show Aider what broke and direct Aider to go back or revert to the previous commit before trying more fixes. 

I have not tested the pre-commit hook behavior with other testing frameworks other than Jest.

### Version and model info

Aider v0.42.0
Models: claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620 with diff edit format, weak model 
claude-3-haiku-20240307
Git repo: .git with 78 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens

.pre-commit-config.yaml
```yaml
repos:
  - repo: local
    hooks:
      - id: run-tests
        name: Run Jest tests
        entry: yarn jest --silent
        language: system
        pass_filenames: false
        files: .*\.(test|spec)\.[jt]sx?$
```
issues.author: rakataprime

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

Yes, aider skips pre-commit hooks by default. You can probably restore them using something like:

```
aider --test-cmd pre-commit
```

The `--test-cmd` is intended to run a command which will do repo-wide checks,  like tests. Aider will attemp

issues.title: When adding large files, aider replies as if the file contents hasn't been passed to the LLM in ollama provider
issues.body:
### Issue

I was testing aider with a larger file (72k) and it seems that when the file exceed the LLM context size, aider simply fails to send any context at all to Ollama and I get a generic answer. Here's a sample session:

```
$ aider --model ollama_chat/qwen2.5-coder:14b
...
> /add pagebrain.js                                                                                                                                                                                                                           

Added pagebrain.js to the chat

pagebrain.js                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  
> explain the contents os pagebrain.js                                                                                                                                                                                                        

I'm sorry, but I cannot provide the contents of pagebrain.js as it is not included in your request. Please provide the content of the file so I can explain its contents to you.
```

I understand that issues are expected with larger files, but it seems aider simply doesn't send any content at all. I think an error should properly explain the issue. 

### Version and model info

Model: ollama_chat/qwen2.5-coder:14b with whole edit format

issues.title: Repository map token limit not respected
issues.body:
### Issue

I am using aider to work on a "larger" git repository. 
I noticed very high input token usage when sending queries to claude-3.5-sonnet. 
Further investigations lead me to believe that aider is currently not respecting the repository map token limit. 
Consider the below snippet, in which i call aider explicitly with "--map-tokens 1024", however the "/tokens" command still reports it to use over 16.000 tokens for the repository map. 
The value reported is consistent with the API usage reports i get from the Anthropic API console. 
I tried deleting the ".aider.tags.cache.v3" directory within the repository folder. 
This lets aider regenerate the repository map cache, however the token usage stays the same.
Setting the map-tokens config key in the ".aider.conf.yml" file in my homedir also does not change the behavior.
Another symptom possibly related is the very slow autocomplete when adding files to the chat. Sometimes it takes several seconds before the list with the suggestions is generated.


```
PS C:\Data\repos\MyLargeProject> aider --map-tokens 1024
Aider v0.40.6
Models: claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620 with diff edit format, weak model claude-3-haiku-20240307
Git repo: .git with 552 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens
Use /help to see in-chat commands, run with --help to see cmd line args
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
> /tokens

Approximate context window usage, in tokens:

$ 0.0034    1,133 system messages
$ 0.0493   16,419 repository map  use --map-tokens to resize
==================
$ 0.0527   17,552 tokens total
          182,448 tokens remaining in context window
          200,000 tokens max context window size
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
>

```

### Version and model info

Aider v0.40.6
Models: claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620 with diff edit format, weak model claude-3-haiku-20240307
Git repo: .git with 552 files
issues.author: hzappen

comments.body:
I did some further testing and found that the "map-tokens" parameter indeed does do something. The repository map size reported by the tokens command approximately halves/doubles when i set "map-tokens" to 512 or 2048:

```
PS C:\Data\repos\MyLargeProject> aider --map-tokens 512
Aider v0.40.6
M

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

The `--map-tokens` option does not specify a hard limit. Aider adjusts the size of the repo map dynamically based on the state of the chat. It will usually stay within that setting's value. But it does expand it significantly at times, especially whe

comments.author: paul-gauthier
comments.body: FYI, the version in the main branch (not yet released) uses somewhat less tokens for repomap.

First, thank you very much for providing this awesome project! And also for the very quick response.

I just tried out the current main branch, and indeed it roughly halves the repo map token usage in my case.

May i suggest updating the documentation to reflect that the value set by `--map-toke

issues.title: With --subtree-only files are created in the git root, not the subtree?
issues.body:
> @paul-gauthier If possible I would like to reopen the issue. `--subtree-only` works fine for controlling the context but it does nothing for creation of new files. When working with monorepo the fact that aider always creates files starting in git root is troublesome. 
> 
> At first I started to disable auto-commit and manually copied each created file to the right folder and only then manually commit. As you can imagine this is against the idea of ai coding assistant when you have to constantly assist aider in the right placement of files.
> At the moment I am using a convoluted `CONVENTIONS.md` to make it work for 50-80% of files which is far from ideal.
> 
> I thought maybe an option like `--cwd-for-new-files` where it would then switch from `git root` to `cwd` for new files.  But the proposal with `/CWD` command is even better as it would allow to dynamically switch the cwd.

issues.title: Consider adding `--subtree-only` to exclude repo content outside the cwd + subtree
issues.body:
> NeverCast: It would be nice if Aider can handle virtual paths so that the agent is essentially sandboxed to a subpath in a Git repo. 

> Examples of this is where server and client implementations might be in the same repo, or there may be many libraries that are part of the project and can't be separated into individual git repos for many sensible reasons, but I'd still like to constrain the agent to focus on one particular area.

> Obviously the Git paths are still going to be relative to root and that's where Aider could handle that.

> paulg: I'm not sure Carter's issue is the result of an intentionally constructed monorepo. But agreed, sometimes it might be sensible to focus aider on a subtree of the repo. Could possibly add a --subtree-only which limits it to only consider paths in/below the cwd.

See discord discussion:

https://discord.com/channels/1131200896827654144/1133060505792159755/1169389326044508220

@nevercast

issues.title: Plugin architecture for aider
issues.body:
### Issue

Feature request - Create a plugin architecture for aider.

This could be used, for example, to create custom commands for Aider. As well as extending the use of Aider, it might encourage more community contribution and "buzz" around Aider.

Some inspiration could be taken from
https://github.com/simonw/llm by Simon Willison, his LLM tool allows the creation of plugins. (He uses https://pluggy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/) See also https://docs.datasette.io/en/stable/plugins.html .

I think that custom commands would be handy for aider, and the ability to easily use it from the command line for 1-shot tasks would be great.

For example, to implement interactive help for Aider itself.
You can clone the aider repo, run aider in the base dir and /load key files, then /ask questions. This can get expensive if you load too many files. However, someone could set up an optimal configuration that minimizes costs but returns useful help for aider. This configuration could be loaded as a plugin "interactive help for aider".

This utility would extend to any bleeding edge or obscure repo. LLMs hallucinate badly about such things that are not seen much in their training data, but a plugin that cloned a repo, /load files and provided much better context would be helpful.
This would be handy during an interactive aider coding session when using a more obscure repo, to provide more context to the LLM for coding.


### Version and model info

_No response_

issues.title: Feature Request: Allow discussion with architect before accepting
issues.body:
I use aider like many others with an architect and editor model. There have been many times I query something, but I notice that the architect misunderstood some point or I did not explain it in enough detail originally. Consequently, the editor model would not program what I would like.

### Old Behavior

In such cases, I would cancel the architect run and re-edit my initial prompt. Sometimes this would carry one a few iterations until I explain my initial prompt well enough that the architect gets it all.

### Proposed Behavior

I would be able to chat directly with the architect until it produces a proposal that I am content with to send over to the editor model.

comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

A nice workflow for this is to chat back and forth in "ask" mode. Then do "/code ok, do that" once you're happy with the plan.

```
$ aider --chat-mode ask

> Design a foo bar

I will put the foo above the bar. 

> No, put it below the bar.

Ok, foo go

issues.title: RepoMap pageranking improvement, especially in large monorepos.
issues.body:
### Issue

Background:

I'm currently working on a tool that automatically fixes TypeScript compilation errors in a large monorepo (800k lines) by scripting `aider` (we are enabling strict mode, and have 10,000+ errors to fix).

The approach I have works well for simple fixes, but `aider` is consistently 'blind' to the types that are directly imported from the target files (which contain the types it would need to understand to fix most issues).

I took a look at the repo map that gets output, and it's dominated by common aliases / imports that occur a lot in the codebase, and with 5000 tokens, nothing within a graph distance of even 1 (e.g. direct imports) is present, which means `aider` is completely blind to the most important information.

After looking at the implementation of [RepoMap](https://github.com/Aider-AI/aider/blob/dba844c7f96ff05ca0ea76659a2f521689d0d324/aider/repomap.py#L226), it looks to me like actually, it is intended to weight references heavily, and this probably works in smaller repos.

I'd like to improve this use case. I'm happy to experiment and open PRs to `aider`, but I wanted to ask your thoughts first before I proceed, as per CONTRIBUTING.md.

This may be solvable through tweaking the weights (and just allowing those weights to be customized by the end user).

This is a fairly naive approach:

```python
        # Determine weight multiplier
        if ident in mentioned_idents:
            mul = 10
        elif ident.startswith('_'):
            mul = 0.1
        else:
            # Here's where we can boost direct imports from chat files
            referencer_is_chat_file = referencer in chat_rel_fnames
            if referencer_is_chat_file:
                mul = 50  # Much higher weight for references from chat files
            else:
                mul = 1
```

But essentially we'd want higher weights for files that are closer to the current file.

### Version and model info

_No response_

Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

Interesting approach. Does that change help you use case?

Also, this doc may be helpful in case you haven't seen it:

https://aider.chat/docs/faq.html#can-i-use-aider-in-a-large-mono-repo

issues.title: Python 3.13 support
issues.body:
Aider must be installed with python 3.9 - 3.12. You can't install it directly with python 3.13.

That said, there are very easy ways for python3.13 users to install aider. These methods will quickly and seamlessly install python3.12 and aider and all its dependencies in an isolated environment.

## With aider-install

```bash
python -m pip install aider-install
aider-install
```



## One-liners

These one-liners will install aider, along with python 3.12 if needed. They are based on the [uv installers](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/).

#### Windows

```powershell
powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://aider.chat/install.ps1 | iex"
```

#### Mac & Linux

Use curl to download the script and execute it with sh:

```bash
curl -LsSf https://aider.chat/install.sh | sh
```

If your system doesn't have curl, you can use wget:

```bash
wget -qO- https://aider.chat/install.sh | sh
```


## Install with uv

You can install aider with uv:

```bash
python -m pip install uv  # If you need to install uv
uv tool install --force --python python3.12 aider-chat@latest
```

This will install uv using your existing python version 3.8-3.13, and use it to install aider. If needed, uv will automatically install a separate python 3.12 to use with aider.

Also see the [docs on other methods for installing uv itself](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/).

issues.title: Feature: Proxy Support for aider
issues.body:
### Issue

**Summary:**

This feature request proposes adding support for using proxies with Aider, the AI pair programming tool.

**Motivation:**

Currently, Aider directly connects to LLM APIs, which can be problematic in certain scenarios:

* **Network Restrictions:** Users behind firewalls or in environments with restricted internet access may be unable to directly connect to LLM APIs.
* **Privacy Concerns:** Some users may prefer routing their requests through a proxy for added privacy.

**Proposed Solution:**

Implement a configuration option within Aider to specify a proxy server address and port. Aider would then route all API requests through this proxy.

**Implementation Details:**

* **Configuration:**

Add a new section to the Aider configuration file  for proxy settings. This section could include fields for:

    * `proxy_host`: The hostname or IP address of the proxy server.
    * `proxy_port`: The port number of the proxy server.
    * `proxy_type`: (Optional) The type of proxy (e.g., HTTP, SOCKS5).
    *  `credentials`: dict to store creds

**Benefits:**

* **Increased Accessibility:** Enables Aider to be used in environments with network restrictions.
* **Enhanced Privacy:** Provides an additional layer of privacy for users concerned about data exposure.
* **Improved Reliability:** Proxies can help mitigate issues caused by network instability or rate limiting.

**Additional Considerations:**

* **Proxy Authentication:** Consider supporting proxy authentication mechanisms (e.g., username/password, API keys) for enhanced security.
* **Proxy Selection:** Allow users to choose from a list of pre-configured proxies or specify custom proxy settings and apply round robin algorithm

By implementing proxy support, Aider can become more versatile and accessible to a wider range of users.

### Version and model info

Aider v0.41.0
Model: gemini/gemini-1.5-pro-latest with diff-fenced edit format
Git repo: .git with 16 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens

issues.title: new feature -  Implementation of Automated File Processing Steps using JSON Configuration
issues.body:
I like the idea to have in Aider-chat a steps.json file  that executes a series of predefined steps to modify, extend, or improve files using a JSON configuration. The system should handle file paths for reading and writing content.

Aider should:
1. Read from a configuration file (`steps.json`) containing an ordered list of operations
2. Execute each step sequentially based on the JSON structure
3. Handle file paths for both reading reference files and writing output
4. Process operations based on configuration parameters
5. when the process finishes , we can use aider normally from terminal

### Configuration Parameters
Each step in the JSON supports the following parameters:
- `prompt`: The instruction to execute
- `confirm`: Whether user confirmation is needed
- `add_terminal`: If terminal output should be added
- `other_possible_request_of_aider`: Additional aider-specific options
- `read_only`: (Optional) Path to a reference file
- `add`:  (Optional)  Path to the output file

### Example Configuration
```json
[
    {
        "prompt": "Create a list of ten visual examples of the first newton law in a markdown section",
        "confirm": true,
        "add_terminal": false,
        "other_possible_request_of_aider": false,
        "read_only": "path/to/reference/file.md",
        "add": "path/to/output/newton_first_law.md"
    },
    {
        "prompt": "improve this list",
        "confirm": true,
        "add_terminal": false,
        "other_possible_request_of_aider": false
    }
]
```

I think this is a really helpful if I want to create syntetic data, in example:
```json
[
    {
        "prompt": "Create a list of ten visual examples of the first newton law in a markdown section",
        "confirm": true,
        "add_terminal": false,
        "other_possible_request_of_aider": false,
 "read_only": "path/to/reference/file.md",
        "add": "path/to/output/newton_first_law.md"

    },
    {
        "prompt": "improve this list",
        "confirm": true,
        "add_terminal": false,
        "other_possible_request_of_aider": false,

    },
    {
        "prompt": "Create a second list of ten visual examples of the first newton law in a markdown section",
        "confirm": true,
        "add_terminal": false,
        "other_possible_request_of_aider": false,

    },
    {
        "prompt": "improve the list of the second law of newton",
        "confirm": true,
        "add_terminal": false,
        "other_possible_request_of_aider": false,

    },
    {
        "prompt": "Create a third list of ten visual examples of the first newton law in a markdown section",
        "confirm": true,
        "add_terminal": false,
        "other_possible_request_of_aider": false,

    },
    {
        "prompt": "improve the list of the second law of newton",
        "confirm": true,

    }
]

```

issues.title: Aider with sonar deletes existing code
issues.body:
### Issue

I can't figure out how to cooperate with Aider. Whenever I ask it to write code, it deletes all existing code.

```
% aider --model perplexity/sonar              
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Aider v0.74.2
Model: perplexity/sonar with whole edit format
Git repo: .git with 385 files
Repo-map: using 4096 tokens, auto refresh
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
> add a function computing factorial(n) to schedule.rs                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      


crates/my_crate/src/schedule.rs
Add file to the chat? (Y)es/(N)o/(D)on't ask again [Yes]:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
To add a function computing factorial(n) to schedule.rs, you can use an iterative approach to calculate the factorial. This method is more efficient than recursion for large numbers because it avoids potential stack overflow issues.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    

Here's how you can implement it:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            

```
Then it shows a diff which deletes every existing line in the file.

What I end up with is a file crates/my_crate/src/schedule.rs that contains literally
```
crates/my_crate/src/schedule.rs
```

Sometimes it would contain
```
// ... existing code ...

/// Calculates the factorial of a given number.
fn factorial(n: u64) -> u64 {
    let mut result = 1;
    for i in 1..=n {
        result *= i;
    }
    result
}

// ... existing code ...
```

Neither of these options are useful.


### Version and model info

Aider v0.74.2
Model: perplexity/sonar with whole edit format

```
 % uname -a
Linux steelspirit 6.13.1-arch1-1 #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Sun, 02 Feb 2025 01:02:29 +0000 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
